<!-- General information --> |timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern (EST)]] |utc_offset = -5 |timezone_DST = EDT |utc_offset_DST = -4 |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_ft = |coordinates = {{coord|27|56|59|N|82|27|23|W|region:US_type:city|display=inline,title}}
<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 33602, 33606 |area_code = |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Downtown Tampa''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Florida]], United States, and the chief financial district of the [[Tampa Bay Area]].
It is second only to [[Westshore, Tampa|Westshore]] regarding employment in the area. Companies with a major presence downtown include [[Bank of America]], [[BB&T]], [[Marshall & Ilsley]], [[PNC Financial Services]], [[SunTrust]], [[Sykes Enterprises]], [[TECO Energy]], and [[Frontier Communications]]. The [[Tampa Convention Center]] is located on the river.
== Description == Downtown Tampa is bounded by the [[Hillsborough River (Florida)|Hillsborough River]] to the west, [[Channel District, Tampa, Florida|Channelside]] to the east, [[Interstate 275 (Florida)|Interstate 275]] to the north, [[Davis Islands, Tampa, Florida|Davis Islands]] and [[Harbour Island (Tampa)|Harbour Island]] to the south. The total area for the area is {{convert|521|acre|km2}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hillsborough.communityatlas.usf.edu/general/default.asp?ID=120571066&level=nbrhd|title=Tampa Downtown Partnership : General Information : Hillsborough Community Atlas|work=usf.edu}}</ref> Historical [[Fort Brooke]] was located at the southern end of downtown Tampa, near the mouth of the [[Hillsborough River (Florida)|Hillsborough River]]. The [[TECO Line Streetcar System|TECO Streetcar]] takes passengers from downtown to other core areas of Tampa.<ref>http://www.tecolinestreetcar.org/about/maps/system_map_6-9-08.pdf{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Municipal services == [[File:Tampa City Hall.jpg|left|thumb|Old Tampa City Hall]] *[[Tampa City Hall]] *[[Tampa Police Department]]
{{Clear}}
== Arts and culture ==
=== Aquarium === [[File:Florida Aquarium Channelside.jpg|thumb|Florida Aquarium|right]] The [[Florida Aquarium]] is a large scale, 250,000-square-foot (23,000 m2) aquarium and is accredited by the [[Association of Zoos and Aquariums]]. The facility is home to more than 20,000 aquatic plants and animals from Florida and all over the world. The facility is located in the Channel District near the SS American Victory and the Port of Tampa's cruise terminals.
=== Museums === [[File:Florida Museum of Photographic Arts.jpg|thumb|left|Florida Museum of Photographic Arts]] *The [[Florida Museum of Photographic Arts]] (FMoPA) occupies the 2nd and 3rd floors of the architecturally significant Cube an adjacent to [[Rivergate Tower]]. FMoPA is part of the Waterfront Arts District, along with the Tampa Museum of Art and Glazer Children's Museum, all located alongside the Tampa Riverwalk.
[[File:Glazer Children's Museum.jpg|thumb|right|Glazer Children's Museum]] *The [[Glazer Children’s Museum]] is located in central downtown, next door to the Tampa Museum of Art and Curtis Hixon Park, alongside the Tampa Riverwalk. It is part of the Waterfront Arts District. Based in a 53,000 square foot facility in downtown Tampa, Florida, the Museum has 170 hands-on exhibits in multiple themed areas. Exhibits are designed to engage children in the discovery process through play.
[[File:Henry Plant Museum.jpg|thumb|left|Henry B. Plant Museum]] *The [[Henry B. Plant Museum]] is located in the south wing of Plant Hall on the University of Tampa’s campus, at 401 West Kennedy Boulevard. The museum's exhibits focus on the [[Gilded Age]] lifestyle of the old Tampa Bay Hotel’s guests during the 1890s, when Tampa was experiencing sudden population and economic growth, including the beginning of the local tourist industry. *The [[SS American Victory]] a [[Victory ship]] built during [[World War II]] and is located in the Channel District near the Florida Aquarium. American Victory was preserved in 1998 to serve as a museum ship. She is the main feature of the American Victory Ship & Museum, also known as the American Victory Mariners Memorial & Museum Ship.<ref>{{cite web |title=SS American Victory |publisher=Landmark: United States |url=http://www.landmarkunitedstates.com/site/18934/SS-American-Victory |accessdate=2011-07-23 }}</ref>
[[File:Tampa Bay History Center 1.jpg|thumb|right|Tampa Bay History Center]] *The [[Tampa Bay History Center]] is history museum located in the southern part of downtown near the Channel District and [[Amalie Arena]]. Exhibits include coverage of the Tampa Bay area's first native inhabitants, Spanish conquistadors, and historical figures who shaped the area's history, as well as a reproduction of a 1920s cigar store.
[[File:Tampa Museum of Art.jpg|thumb|Tampa Museum of Art|Tampa Museum of Art]]
*The [[Tampa Museum of Art]] is located in central downtown, next door to the Glazer Children’s Museum and Curtis Hixon Park, alongside the Tampa Riverwalk. The museum was founded in 1979 and debuted an innovative new building in 2010 on the banks of Hillsborough River just north of its original site. The current location is part of Tampa's Riverwalk and the Waterfront Arts District along with the Glazer Children's Museum and the Florida Museum of Photographic Arts and includes a gift shop and SONO Cafe, a restaurant operated by Mise En Place.
=== Performing Arts === [[File:Tbpac.JPG|left|thumb|[[The David A. Straz Jr. Center for the Performing Arts|The Straz Center]], formerly called Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center (TBPAC)]]
The [[Straz Center for the Performing Arts|David A. Straz Jr. Center for the Performing Arts]] opened its doors as the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center, Tampa, Florida in July 1987 and has welcomed more than 10 million guests. The Straz Center is located in northern downtown on a 9-acre (36,000 m2) site along the east bank of the Hillsborough River. As the second largest performing arts complex in the Southeastern United States (behind the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts), the 335,000-square-foot (31,100 m2) venue provides an environment for a variety of events. It has a leading Broadway series, produces grand opera, is the home of the resident professional theater company [[Jobsite Theater]], and also presents a wide variety of concerts and other events.
=== Theaters ===
[[File:Tampa Theater.jpg|thumb|left|Tampa Theater]] The [[Tampa Theatre]] a historic [[U.S. theater]] and city landmark in the Uptown District of downtown Tampa, Florida. On January 3, 1978, it was added to the [[U.S. National Register of Historic Places]]. The Theatre features a wide range of independent, foreign, and documentary films on a daily basis. It is Tampa's only non-profit movie theater and operating costs are largely covered by its membership program, various corporate sponsors as well as ticket sales. It has periodically been used as a backdrop for movies, MTV videos and local programming.
== Downtown Districts ==
=== Uptown District === {{main|Uptown Tampa}} Also known as the '''River Arts District''', this northwestern chunk of downtown contains the majority of nightlife and dining in the neighborhood. Important cultural landmarks such as [[Tampa Theatre]], [[Straz Center for the Performing Arts]], the John F. Germany public library, [[Glazer Children's Museum]], and the [[Tampa Museum of Art]] are all centered around [[Curtis Hixon Waterfront Park]], which has been called "Tampa's town square".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampagov.net/news/renovations-underway-curtis-hixon-waterfront-park|title=Renovations Underway Curtis Hixon Waterfront Park|work=City of Tampa}}</ref> Collectively, this area represents the focal point of downtown proper due to having a large concentration of interest points and establishments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2010-09-24/travel/os-travel-tampa-childrens-museum-20100924_1_channel-district-new-arts-new-museums|title=Children's museum strengthens Tampa's arts district|work=tribunedigital-orlandosentinel}}</ref>
=== Channel District === Although technically downtown, [[Channel District, Tampa|Channelside]] is often thought to be adjacent to the main CBD. This district is the location for many prominent downtown venues. The [[Tampa Convention Center]], [[Amalie Arena]], [[Tampa Bay History Center]], the [[Florida Aquarium]] and the [[SS American Victory]] are located in the Channel District. Twin 30 story condos were completed in 2007, called the [[Towers of Channelside]]. Many other residential mid and high-rises have been completed since.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/01/02/Citytimes/Towers_viewed_as_bles.shtml|title=Citytimes: Towers viewed as blessing, curse|work=sptimes.com}}</ref> Many locals know the Channel District (often abbreviated to Channelside in local parlance) for its nightlife. The [[Channelside Bay Plaza]], which has views of the downtown skyline, is located in the middle of the district.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/051301/Columns/Channelside_woos_nigh.shtml|title=Columns: Channelside woos night life; singles seek a match|work=sptimes.com}}</ref> Entrepreuners have founded companies that operate [[Neighborhood Electric Vehicle|NEVs]] to shuttle clubgoers to/from Channelside and Tampa's other core districts: [[Hyde Park, Tampa|Hyde Park]], [[Soho, Tampa|SoHo]], Downtown, and [[Ybor City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.tbo.com/content/2009/apr/07/agency-discuss-regulating-golf-cart--vehicles/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121209021801/http://www2.tbo.com/content/2009/apr/07/agency-discuss-regulating-golf-cart--vehicles/ |archivedate=2012-12-09 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/transportation/article459794.ece|title=Hop Tampa ready to give folks a ride downtown|work=Tampa Bay Times|access-date=2009-07-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607052533/http://www.tampabay.com/news/transportation/article459794.ece|archive-date=2011-06-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
=== University Area === The University area is the city's educational hub and is the location of [[The University of Tampa]] a medium sized private co-educational university. Making up the City's western boundary and located just across the Hillsborough River from downtown the university is home to 6,900 students.
=== Encore === The northern half of downtown is undergoing huge construction projects including retail, condos, and a large grocery store. The district, which will fill the gray zone between Downtown and [[Ybor City, Tampa|Historic Ybor]], will be called "Encore" and will be a "city within a city." <sup>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100326173401/http://www2.tbo.com/content/2010/mar/24/job-fair-one-downtowns-largest-projects/news-breaking/]</sup><sup>[http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/realestate/construction-job-fair-in-tampa-draws-thousands-of-applicants/1082786]</sup> <sup>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100511021838/http://www.encoretampa.com/index.php]</sup> A stimulus grant amounting $38 million was secured to help fund the project, the remaining to be derived from private funding. It is expected to create thousands of jobs for the area including at least 1,000 permanent ones. <sup>[http://www.review.net/print/tampas-encore-project-awarded-38-million-grant/]</sup><sup>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/36034368/ns/local_news-tampa_fl/]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</sup><sup>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101128212929/http://southtampa2.tbo.com/content/2010/nov/24/010000/sprawling-encore-project-under-way/]</sup> The district is being created with its African-American heritage in mind, having been built over the site of the former Central Avenue Business District and later Central Park housing project.
=== Riverwalk === [[File:Tampa architectural photos 256.jpg|thumb|right|The Riverwalk alongside [[Curtis Hixon Park]] ]] {{main|Tampa Riverwalk}} The Tampa Riverwalk is a 2.4 mile long walking and biking trail that winds along the edge of Tampa's downtown, running along the [[Hillsborough River (Florida)|Hillsborough River]] and the [[Garrison Channel]] from the [[Channel District]] on the southeast end to [[Water Works Park (Tampa, Florida)|Waterworks Park]] to the northwest. The Riverwalk's wide pathways, boardwalks, and bridges connect most of Tampa's waterfront parks, attractions, sports and entertainment venues, and hotels, including the [[Tampa Convention Center]], [[Amalie Arena]], the [[Straz Center]], and many others.<ref name="Riverwalk-city">{{cite web | url=http://www.tampagov.net/riverwalk | title=The Tampa Riverwalk | publisher=City of Tampa | accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref>
The idea for the Riverwalk was first proposed by mayor [[Bill Poe]] in the mid-1970s as a way to redevelop Tampa's downtown waterfront, which had long been dominated by large warehouses, port facilities, and other industrial uses. The project was initiated in 1976 with a short walkway of wooden planks behind old [[Curtis Hixon Hall]]. However, funding and interest waned, and the project stalled for almost 30 years until mayor [[Pam Iorio]] made completing the project a city priority upon taking office in 2003. Construction began in phases in the mid-2000s, and the originally planned Riverwalk was completed in 2016, with further extensions to be added on both ends. The total cost of the completed project will be about $32 million, with most of the funds coming the city of Tampa along with a $11 million grant from the [[United States Department of Transportation]].<ref name="Riverwalk-friends">{{cite web | url=http://www.thetampariverwalk.com/about/history.aspx | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107124317/http://www.thetampariverwalk.com/about/history.aspx | dead-url=yes | archive-date=7 January 2015 | title=History of the Tampa Riverwalk | publisher=Friends of the Tampa Riverwalk | accessdate=7 July 2016 }}</ref>
== Hotels and Accommodations == Downtown Tampa has 9 hotels located throughout the downtown core that create a total of 2,791 rooms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampasdowntown.com/learn/newspr/reports/downtown-quick-facts.aspx#Hotels___Conventions:|title=Downtown Tampa Facts – Learn about Downtown Tampa – Tampa Downtown Partnership|work=tampasdowntown.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131122220530/http://www.tampasdowntown.com/learn/newspr/reports/downtown-quick-facts.aspx#Hotels___Conventions:|archivedate=2013-11-22|df=}}</ref> Major hotels in downtown are:
* Courtyard by Marriott Tampa Downtown with 141 rooms is located in northern downtown in the arts district. * [[Embassy Suites]] Tampa Downtown with 360 rooms is located in the south part of downtown and is connected via skybridge to the Tampa Convention Center. * [[Barrymore Hotel]] Plaza Hotel with 316 rooms * Hilton Hotel Downtown Tampa with 521 rooms<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/two-new-names-coming-to-old-downtown-tampa-hyatt-hilton-and-starbucks/1269040|title=Two new names coming to old downtown Tampa Hyatt: Hilton and Starbucks|work=Tampa Bay Times}}</ref> * Residence Inn By Marriott Tampa Downtown with 109 rooms is located in northern downtown in the arts district. * Sheraton Tampa Riverwalk Hotel<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sheratontampariverwalk.com/|title=Sheraton Tampa Riverwalk official site|work=sheratontampariverwalk.com}}</ref> with 277 rooms is located in the center of downtown and sits along the Hillsborough River and the riverwalk. * Tampa Marriott Waterside Hotel and Marina with 719 rooms is in southern downtown and is situated between the convention center and the Tampa Bay Times Forum. * [[Westin Hotels]] Harbour Island with 299 rooms is located on [[Harbour Island (Tampa)]] and is just south of the convention center.
The following are boutique hotels:
* [[Aloft Hotels]] is in the former 8 story Mercantile Bank building. The hotel has 130 rooms and includes Aloft brand’s signature W XYZ bar and is located along the Hillsborough River<ref>{{cite web|url=http://development.starwoodhotels.com/news/1/516-aloft_hotels_debuts_in_tampa|title=News|work=starwoodhotels.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411210353/http://development.starwoodhotels.com/news/1/516-aloft_hotels_debuts_in_tampa|archivedate=2013-04-11|df=}}</ref> * [[Floridan Palace Hotel]] with 193 rooms, 15 Junior Executive Suites, and 3 Penthouse Suits<ref>{{cite web|url=http://floridanpalace.com/key-facts-services-amenities/|title=Key Facts, Services & Amenities – Floridan hotel – Tampa FL – Indulge yourself in old world charm, met with the modern comforts of today.|author=ThemeFuse|work=floridanpalace.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121229234042/http://floridanpalace.com/key-facts-services-amenities/|archivedate=2012-12-29|df=}}</ref> is located in northern downtown near the [[Tampa Theatre]] * [[Le Méridien]] with 130 rooms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cltampa.com/dailyloaf/archives/2013/02/13/former-tampa-courthouse-to-become-le-mridien-hotel-and-restaurant#.UR5d2aWG7zI|title=Former Tampa courthouse to become Le Méridien hotel and restaurant|work=Creative Loafing Tampa}}</ref>
== Transportation == [[File:Trolley at Franklin and Whiting Street.jpg|thumb|right|Street Car at Franklin and Whiting Street]] [[Hillsborough Area Regional Transit]] (HART) operates Tampa's public transportation. HART operates many bus lines through downtown and also operates the [[TECO Line Streetcar System]], a 2.4 miles streetcar line that extends from central downtown through Channelside and into [[Ybor]]. HART's main hub, the Marion Transit Center is located in the north end of downtown and is serviced by 30 local and express routes and a future stop for HART's MetroRapid Green Line.
== See also == *[[Bayshore Boulevard]], street known for its long sidewalk and waterfront view. Runs due southwest from downtown to Hyde Park and [[Soho, Tampa|SoHo]] *[[Harbour Island, Tampa|Harbour Island]], adjacent to downtown and channelside south across the [[Garrison Channel]]. *[[Hyde Park, Tampa|Hyde Park]], historic neighborhood southwest of downtown abutting Bayshore and Kennedy Blvd. *[[Tampa Heights, Tampa|Tampa Heights]], historic neighborhood just north of downtown, will be northern end of Riverwalk upon its completion around 2010. *[[Westshore, Tampa|Westshore]], a business district located adjacent to [[Tampa International Airport]] and [[Rocky Point, Tampa, Florida|Rocky Point]]. This area actually eclipses downtown itself for most jobs in the region. *[[Ybor City]], historic district adjacent to downtown from the northeast.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.tampagov.net/ Official City of Tampa Website] *[http://www.tampasdowntown.com/ Official Tourism Website] *[http://www.813area.com/tampa/downtown-tampa/ Downtown Tampa Guide] *[http://www.hillsborough.communityatlas.usf.edu/general/default.asp?ID=120571066&level=nbrhd Tampa Downtown – Hillsborough Community Atlas] *[http://www.tampapix.com/ Collection of historic downtown Tampa photos]

'''EasyLanguage''' is a proprietary [[programming language]] that was developed by [[TradeStation]] and built into its [[electronic trading platform]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tradestation.com/strategy_testing/st_creation.shtm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121224930/http://www.tradestation.com/strategy_testing/st_creation.shtm |archivedate=2009-11-21 |df= }}</ref> It is used to create custom indicators for financial charts and also to create [[algorithmic trading]] strategies for the markets. External [[Dynamic-link library|DLL]]'s can be referenced using EasyLanguage which greatly extends its functionality.
The language was intended to allow creation of custom trading strategies by traders without specialized computer training. Commands consist mostly of regular English words, which makes EasyLanguage easier to learn than more complex programming languages.<ref>http://lambda-the-ultimate.org/node/2201</ref>
Example: * Plain English: "If the close is greater than the high of 1 day ago, then buy 100 shares at market." * EasyLanguage: "if the Close > the High of 1 day ago then Buy 100 shares next bar at market;"
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.tradestation.com TradeStation Securities, Inc]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Easylanguage}} [[Category:Business software]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = First Isabela Cooperative Bank | logo = File:FICOBANK_Company_logo.png | type = [[Private company|Cooperative Bank]] | foundation = Cauayan City, Isabela, Philippines (1976) | location = Maharlika Hwy., Minante 1, [[Cauayan City, Isabela]], Philippines | key_people = Erwin B. Tabucol
{{small|(Chairman of the Board)}}
Atty. Hubert E. Molina
{{small|(President & CEO)}} | num_employees = 449 | industry = [[Finance]] | products = [[Financial Services]] | net_income = {{Philippine peso|131.43 million}} (2017) | assets = {{Philippine peso|4.11 billion}} (2017) | homepage = {{URL|http://www.ficobank.com.ph}} }} '''First Isabela Cooperative Bank'''{{cite book|title=First Isabela Cooperative Bank|url=http://www.ficobank.com/corpoprofile.htm}}, stylized as '''FICOBank'''{{cite book|title=FICOBank|url=http://www.ficobank.com/visualidentity.htm}}, is a cooperative bank started in the mid-1970s. It is primarily engaged in financial intermediation between and among: [[farmer]]s, [[fisherman|fishers]] and their organizations; micro, small and medium [[entrepreneurs]]; rural, urban and overseas workers; and professionals, pensioners and other segments of the market. It also provides mobile-money, money-transfer/remittance and cash-dispensing services to the public. As of June 2018, FICOBank has 34 banking units located in the provinces of Isabela, Quirino, Nueva Vizcaya, Cagayan, Tarlac, Nueva Ecija, Bataan, Pampanga, Pangasinan and Bulacan. == History == The Philippine Cooperative Program of the ‘70s during the [[Ferdinand Marcos|Marcos administration]] paved the way for the organization of cooperative banks in the country. A group of technocrats led by Dr. Orlando J. Sacay, the recognized father of the [[Philippine]] cooperative banking system, worked for the enactment of Presidential Decree 175, espousing the formation of economic institutions or [[Cooperative|cooperatives]]. Composed of small farmers, these cooperatives were primarily organized to look after their own interests. To serve as foundation of the cooperative rural banks and area marketing cooperatives, ''samahang nayon'' (pre-cooperatives) were organized in the rural areas. Thus, the triangular approach to rural development—production (under the ''samahang nayon''), credit (under a cooperative rural bank), and marketing (under an area marketing cooperative)—was put into operation. It was envisioned that there would be social equity, if these three vital functions of rural development will be placed in the hands of the farmers. In 1973, the Regional Cooperative Development Program for Cagayan Valley (RCDP-CV) was launched to develop the farming communities of the region. With financial assistance from the [[Canadian International Development Agency]], the program sought to: improve farm productivity; diversify [[agricultural]] production; increase household income; and install a system of cooperatives, as an indispensable support mechanism. The institution of the cooperative rural banking system, as a major component of the program, was in line with the recognition of the importance of rural finance for development. The [[Bank]] was officially formed on September 10, 1976{{cite book|title=Milestones|url=http://www.ficobank.com/milestone.htm}} . It was the time when the authorized representatives of two cooperatives and 47 ''samahang nayon'' unanimously agreed and voluntarily joined together to establish a cooperative rural bank in the [[province of Isabela]]. The primordial objective for its establishment was to provide financing to farmers and small entrepreneurs who have limited resources and access to banking services. Originally, the Bank was registered with the [[Securities and Exchange Commission (Philippines)|Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)]], as First Isabela Cooperative Rural Bank Inc. (FICRBI). On February 14, 1979, it acquired its juridical personality through SEC’s stamp of approval and registration. It was re-registered with the Bureau of Cooperative Development of the Ministry of Local Government and Community Development (BCOD-MLGCD) on April 10, 1979, under Certificate of Registration No. FF-119. The Central Bank of the Philippines granted the Bank its Certificate of Authority, numbered B-1000, on December 21, 1979 to operate as a cooperative rural bank. As such, it is vested with the rights to exercise all authority and powers, to do and perform all acts and to transact all businesses, which may be legally done by rural banks under the Rural Banking Act, and to do all other things incident thereto, as may be determined by the Monetary Board of the [[Central Bank of the Philippines]] (now known as Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas). The Bank was formally inaugurated on January 2, 1980. Being a cooperative bank, FICRBI (now FICOBank) is under the supervision of both the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) and the Cooperative Development Authority (CDA). The latter was created by the enactment of Republic Act 6939. Together with Republic Act 6938 or the 1990 Cooperative Code of the Philippines, they are known as the twin Cooperative Laws of the country. In compliance with the provisions of the said laws, FICOBank obtained CDA’s confirmation of its registration, as a cooperative bank. Its Certificate of Confirmation, numbered 661, was issued by CDA on March 11, 1991. After staying at the CAVADECO compound in [[Cauayan City, Isabela]] for about 15 years, FICOBank moved out and began its branching initiative to other parts of the province and its neighboring provinces in the region. In 1995, it opened its first branch in [[Roxas, Isabela]]. This was followed, in succession, by its branches in [[Alicia, Isabela|Alicia]] and Cauayan City, both in Isabela, in 1996. The Maddela Branch in [[Quirino province]] was opened in 1998. In the same year, its Jones Branch, also in Isabela, became its fifth branch. In 2003, its Cauayan Branch was transferred to [[Santiago (Philippine city)|Santiago City]]. A year later, the Bank’s Corporate Office—the nerve center of its operations—was inaugurated in its present location in Cauayan City, Isabela. A branch in [[Dupax del Sur]], the first operating unit of the Bank in the province of [[Nueva Vizcaya]], was also opened in the same year. It was later transferred to the municipality of [[Solano, Nueva Vizcaya|Solano]]. FICOBank established its foothold in the whole region by opening its branch in [[Solana, Cagayan]] in 2005. Few years later, two field offices in [[Diffun, Quirino]] and [[Aurora, Isabela]] were opened, and two more branches in the municipalities of [[ Paniqui, Tarlac|Paniqui]] and [[Concepcion, Tarlac|Concepcion in Tarlac]] were inaugurated. Field offices in [[San Mateo, Isabela|San Mateo]], [[Ilagan, Isabela|Ilagan City]], [[Echague, Isabela|Echague]], [[Tumauini, Isabela|Tumauini]] and [[Cabagan, Isabela|Cabagan]]—all in Isabela—and in [[Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya]] were opened, one after the other. The Bank also opened one branch each in the municipalities of [[Dinalupihan, Bataan|Dinalupihan]] and Orani in Bataan and in [[Cabanatuan City, Nueva Ecija|Cabanatuan City in Nueva Ecija]], all in Region III. In 2009, FICOBank opened its five new branches, one in [[Cagayan]] and four in [[Pangasinan]]. The northernmost town of Aparri is the site of the new branch in Cagayan, while the municipalities of Umingan, Malasiqui, Lingayen and Mangaldan are the locations of the new branches of the Bank in the province of Pangasinan. The Orani Branch in Bataan was also transferred to Urdaneta City in Pangasinan in the same year. The Bank’s 27th operating unit was officially opened in Tuguegarao City in 2010. Its field offices were converted into extension offices, and all became full-fledged branches afterward. Its banking offices in Umingan (Pangasinan), Cabagan (Isabela) and Mangaldan (Pangasinan) were transferred to Guimba (Nueva Ecija), Gapan City (Nueva Ecija) and San Fernando City (Pampanga), respectively. Later on, five more branches were opened in Cauayan City (Isabela), Baliwag (Bulacan), and San Jose City, Rizal and Zaragoza (all in Nueva Ecija). In December 2017, the Bank inaugurated its 33rd banking unit in [[Abulug, Cagayan|Abulug (Cagayan)]]. And six (6) months later thereafter, FICOBank opened another branch in Cagayan, particularly in Gonzaga. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[List of banks in the Philippines]] *[http://www.listph.com/2015/08/list-of-thrift-and-rural-cooperative-banks-with-demand-deposits-in-philippines.html List of Thrift and Rural/Cooperative Banks with Demand Deposits in the Philippines] ==External links== *[http://www.ficobank.com/index.htm FICOBank Website] *[http://www.microfinancecouncil.org/first-isabela-cooperative-bank-fico-bank First Isabela Cooperative Bank (FICOBank)] *[http://microfinancecouncil.blogspot.hk/2009_06_01_archive.html MCPI Partners] *[http://www.ficobank.com/marketFootprints.html Market Footprints] *[http://www.ficobank.com/corpoidentity.htm Corporate Identity] *[http://www.ficobank.com/inspursuits.htm Strategic Pursuits] *[http://www.ficobank.com/corporateDNA.htm Corporate DNA] *[http://www.listph.com/2015/08/list-of-thrift-and-rural-cooperative-banks-with-demand-deposits-in-philippines.html List of Thrift and Rural/Cooperative Banks with Demand Deposits in the Philippines] *[http://listofbanksin.com/ListofBanksinPhilippines.htm Banks in Philippines] [[Category:Banks of the Philippines]] {{Business-stub}}

Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House) |website=Beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |date=2015-12-21 |accessdate=2017-02-24}} is a Spanish businessman, and the vice-chairman and CEO of [[Meliá Hotels International]].{{cite web|url=http://www.meliahotelsinternational.com/en/about-us/management-structure |title=Management structure | Meliá Hotels International |website=Meliahotelsinternational.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} He is the son of the founder and chairman, [[Gabriel Escarrer|Gabriel Escarrer Juliá]].{{cite web|last=O'Ceallaigh |first=John |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/travel/21830/the-business-gabriel-escarrer-jaume.html |title=The Business: Gabriel Escarrer Jaume |publisher=Telegraph |date=2014-01-17 |accessdate=2017-02-24}} Escarrer Jaume has a degree from the Wharton School, [[University of Pennsylvania]], where he specialized in Finance & Business Management.{{cite web|url=http://hotelspaceonline.com/people/gabriel-escarrer-jaume-vice-chairman-and-ceo-at-melia-hotels-international/ |title=Gabriel Escarrer Jaume, Vice Chairman And Ceo At Melia Hotels International - Space | International Hotel Design |website=Hotelspaceonline.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} He has a master's degree in Business Administration from [[ESADE]].{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/stocks |title=Stocks |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} Escarrer Jaume worked in New York City in finance, before joining Meliá Hotels. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Escarrer Jaume, Gabriel}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Spanish businesspeople]] {{Spain-business-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = George Barnes |honorific-suffix = |image = George Powell Barnes - Queensland politician.png |caption = | constituency_AM1 = [[Electoral district of Warwick|Warwick]] | assembly1 = Queensland Legislative | term_start1 = 5 February 1908 | term_end1 = 11 May 1935 | predecessor1 = [[Thomas O'Sullivan]] | successor1 = [[John Healy (Australian politician)|John Healy]]
|birth_date = {{Birth date|1856|9|20|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Castlemaine, Victoria|Castlemaine]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia |death_date = {{death date and age|1949|12|9|1856|9|20|df=y}} |death_place = [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], Australia |restingplace = [[Warwick Cemetery]]<ref name=courier1>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49695795 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |location=Brisbane |date=10 December 1949 |accessdate=27 January 2015 |page=16 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> |birthname = George Powell Barnes |nationality = Australian |party = Ministerialist |otherparty = [[Liberal Party (Queensland, 1908)|Liberal Party]], [[National Party (Queensland, 1917)|National Party]], [[Country and Progressive National Party]] |spouse = Mary Cecilia Merry (m.1879 d.1942) | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Businessman]] | relations = [[Hiram Barnes]] (father), [[Walter Barnes (politician)|Walter Barnes]] (brother) | religion = [[Methodist]] }}
'''George Powell Barnes''' (20 September 1856 – 9 December 1949), generally referred to by his full name or as "George P. Barnes",<ref group="N">Most likely to distinguish him in newspaper reports from his contemporary, the prominent British parliamentarian [[George Barnes (British politician)|George Barnes]].</ref> was a Queensland businessman and politician.
==Early life== George was a son of Cobb and Co. pioneer [[Hiram Barnes]] and a brother of [[Walter Barnes (politician)|Walter Barnes MLA]].
==Business interests==
George Barnes started the company Barnes and Company Limited in 1880 in association with his brother, [[Walter Henry Barnes]] and Mr TF Merry. Merry was a storekeeper in [[Toowoomba]], with whom George worked earlier and whose daughter, Mary Cecelia was married to George in 1879. Barnes and Co was formed to control businesses in Warwick, [[Allora, Queensland|Allora]], [[Yangan, Queensland|Yangan]] and Roma Street and Commonwealth Flour Mills at [[Warwick, Queensland|Warwick]] and [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]].<ref name=qhr>{{cite QHR|15731|Barnes and Co. Trading Place|600956|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
He was a leading figure in the Warwick Methodist Church and the Warwick Ambulance Brigade.
==Politics== He was member for [[Electoral district of Warwick|Warwick]] for 27 years, from 1908 to 1935, when he retired.<ref name=qp>{{cite web|title=Former Members|publisher=[[Parliament of Queensland]]|year=2015| url=http://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/members/former/bio?id=3301486626|accessdate= 27 January 2015}}</ref>
==Family== He married Mary Cecilia Merry (ca.1858 – 3 October 1942) of [[Bulimba, Queensland]] in 1879. She was active in the local Methodist Church, Red Cross Society and Benevolent Society; they had a home "Glen Lyn" in [[Warwick, Queensland|Warwick]].
A son, [[Franklin George Barnes]] (ca.1883 – ) was a mining engineer who devised and patented a method for [[degaussing]] British ships to counter the threat of [[magnetic mine]]s in the early days of World War II.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41943188 |title=Outwitted Nazis. |newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |location=Brisbane |date=2 August 1941 |accessdate=11 May 2014 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48742837|title=Inventor Of Degaussing Device Describes Famous Safeguard|date=4 February 1942|newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)]]|accessdate=23 January 2018|issue=26001|location=South Australia|volume=LXXXIV,|page=8|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Another son, Cecil Merry Barnes, lost his life savings when his company, Barnes Ltd. of [[Fortitude Valley]] was forced into liquidation. G. P. Barnes felt his son's failure acutely, and personally paid out the company's [[preference share]]holders.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40855508 |title=Lost £16,000, Is Now Selling Flour. |newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |location=Brisbane |date=4 August 1939 |accessdate=11 May 2014 |page=9 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Legacy== The former [[Barnes and Co. Trading Place]] in Warwick is listed on the [[Queensland Heritage Register]].<ref name=qhr/>
== Notes == <references group="N" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{s-start}} {{s-par|au-qld }} {{s-bef | before = [[Thomas O'Sullivan]]}} {{s-ttl |title = Member for [[Electoral district of Warwick|Warwick]]|years=1908–1935}} {{s-aft | after = [[John Healy (Australian politician)|John Healy]]}} {{s-end}}

{{Infobox person | name = Gerald Chan | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Gerald Lok Chan | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |64|2018|09|19}} | birth_place = Hong Kong | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = American | education = [[UCLA]]
[[Harvard University]] | occupation = Businessman | known for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = US$2.0 billion (jointly with brother, September 2018){{cite web |title=Forbes profile: Ronnie & Gerald Chan |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/ronnie-gerald-chan/ |website=Forbes |accessdate=19 September 2018}} | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = Beryl W. Chan | children = 2 sons | parents = [[T.H. Chan]] | relatives = [[Ronnie Chan]] (brother) | website = }} '''Gerald L. Chan''' (born 1953/1954) is a Hong Kong-born American [[billionaire]], and the brother of fellow billionaire [[Ronnie Chan]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/ronnie-gerald-chan/|title=Ronnie & Gerald Chan|author=|date=|website=forbes.com|accessdate=19 September 2018}} They run the [[Hang Lung Group]], of which he is a director. ==Early life== Gerald Chan is the son of [[T.H. Chan]]. He earned BS and MS degrees in Engineering from [[UCLA]], and a master's degree in Medical Radiological Physics and doctorate in Radiation Biology from [[Harvard University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.geraldchan.net/about-me/|title=About - Dr. Gerald Chan|author=|date=|website=www.geraldchan.net|accessdate=19 September 2018}} In the 1970s, he became a US citizen. ==Career== In 1987, he co-founded Morningside, a private equity group. He is a director of [[Hang Lung Group]], [[Stealth Peptides]], [[Advanced Cell Diagnostics]], [[Matrivax]], [[Vaccine Technologies Inc]], and [[Oxyrane]].{{cite web|url=http://hcf.fas.harvard.edu/profiles/gerald-l-chan/|title=Gerald L. Chan - Harvard China Fund|author=|date=|website=hcf.fas.harvard.edu|accessdate=19 September 2018}} When his family gave [[Harvard School of Public Health]] $350 million, the largest donation ever given to Harvard, the school was renamed the [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]] for Chan's late father.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2015/05/02/meet-boston-invisible-billionaire/y7QS6m7SniIqsED91iS9oO/story.html|title=Gerald Chan, Boston’s invisible billionaire - The Boston Globe|author=|date=|website=bostonglobe.com|accessdate=19 September 2018}}[https://www.lllsearches.com/uploads/career/files/Harvard-University-SD-University-Development-Office-International-Asia-Principal-Gifts-Backgrounder.pdf Announcement of major search for Senior Director, University Development Office International – Asia Principal Gifts, Harvard University Cambridge, MA] As of 2015, he had invested $500 million in the [[Harvard Square]] district of Cambridge, where he reportedly lives. ==Personal life== Chan is married to Beryl, and they have two sons, Ashley being the eldest. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chan, Gerald}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:Hong Kong billionaires]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:Chan family]] [[Category:1950s births]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Hong Kong philanthropists]] [[Category:Harvard School of Public Health alumni]] [[Category:American people of Chinese descent]] {{US-business-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Background */
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2018}} A {{Nihongo||合同会社|'''gōdō gaisha'''}}, or godo kaisha, abbreviated '''GK''', is a type of [[Company|business organization]] in [[Japan]] modeled after the American [[limited liability company]] (LLC). It is a type of [[mochibun kaisha]] ([[corporation]] having a simplified internal structure like that of a [[partnership]]) distinguished by offering [[limited liability]] for all investors.
==Background==
Gōdō gaisha was newly introduced by the [[Law of Japan|Companies Act]], which became effective on May 1, 2006.
==Basic structure==
A GK is formed by {{nihongo|articles of incorporation|定款|teikan}} signed between its investors, called {{nihongo|members|社員|shain}}. Each member may provide a capital contribution in the form of money or property. Credit and promises to perform services are not valid consideration for an ownership interest in a GK.
Following ratification of the agreement, the GK's articles of incorporation and corporate seal must be registered with the {{nihongo|Legal Affairs Bureau|法務局|hōmukyoku}}. Once the bureau processes the registration, the company may open a bank account, seal contracts, and engage in other activities as a [[Juristic person|legal entity]].
The members may, either in the agreement or pursuant to the agreement, choose a {{nihongo|manager|執行社員|shikkō shain}} from among their ranks. This manager can be either an individual or a corporation; however, corporate managers must appoint a {{nihongo|functional manager|業務執行社員|gyōmu shikkō shain}} to perform the actual management duties.
The legal duties of GK managers are very similar to the legal duties of KK directors. GK members may sue managers in the same way that KK shareholders may sue directors on the company's behalf.
A GK may be converted to a KK with the unanimous consent of all of its members.
==Distinguishing characteristics==
The following distinguish godo gaisha from [[kabushiki gaisha]]:
* All members must consent to amendment of the articles of incorporation, unless the articles of incorporation provide otherwise. (In a KK, only a supermajority of shareholders is required.) * All members must consent to any transfer of ownership, unless the articles of incorporation provide otherwise. (In a KK, the transfer of shares is unlimited by default.) * All members are representatives of the company by default, unless managers have been appointed. (In a KK, only the [[Representative Director (Japan)|Representative Director]] represents the company.) * Major business decisions (such as large asset sales or winding up of the company) may be made informally. (In a KK, resolutions of shareholder and board meetings are often required for such decisions). * Members may invest any type of asset in exchange for their interest. (In a KK, non-cash contributions require an appraisal supervised by a court.) * Because KKs traditionally required a larger capital and procedural investment, GKs did not initially have the same level of prestige. That has changed with many large companies, including Apple, Exxon Mobil and Amazon, opting for GKs in Japan.
==Taxation==
GKs are taxed as corporations under Japanese law: the company's profits are taxed at corporate tax rates, and dividends are taxed at individual tax rates.
In late 2005, following the passage of the Companies Act, the [[Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry]] pressed the [[Ministry of Finance (Japan)|Ministry of Finance]] to treat GKs as "pass-through entities" in which only company profits would be taxed. However, the Ministry of Finance refused to allow such treatment. As a result, many new companies are expected to use the more prestigious KK business form rather than the GK business form, especially given the looser regulation of KKs under the new law. The only limited liability business which receives pass-through tax treatment in Japan is the [[limited liability partnership]].
Under [[United States]] tax law, gōdō gaisha are not classified as corporations, and are therefore eligible to make an [[entity classification election]]: a single-member GK may be treated as an extension of its member and a multi-member GK may follow the tax rules for [[partnership]]s.
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== * [[Gōmei gaisha]] * [[Gōshi gaisha]] * [[Kabushiki gaisha]] * [[Yūgen gaisha]]
==External links== {{Portal|Japan|Companies}} * [http://www.jetro.go.jp/en/invest/setting_up/ Japan External Trade Organization, "Setting Up a Business in Japan"] * [http://www.ron.gr.jp/law/law/kaisha3.htm Company Law provisions regarding godo gaisha] (Japanese) * [http://itpro.nikkeibp.co.jp/article/SMBIT/20051213/226161/ New Company Law and Godo Gaisha] (Japanese)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Godo Gaisha}} [[Category:Japanese business law]] [[Category:Japanese business terms]] [[Category:Types of business entity]]

{{Like resume|date=November 2014}} '''Howard Moskowitz''' is an American [[market research]]er and [[Psychophysics|psychophysicist]]. He is best known for the detailed study he made of the types of [[Tomato sauce|spaghetti sauce]] and horizontal segmentation. By providing a large number of options for consumers, Moskowitz pioneered the idea of [[intermarket variability]] as applied to the [[food industry]].<ref>{{cite book |title=What The Dog Saw |last=Gladwell |first=Malcolm |authorlink=Malcolm Gladwell |year=2009 |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |isbn=0-316-07584-1 |page=432}}</ref>
Howard Moskowitz is the CEO of i-Novation Inc as well as President of Moskowitz Jacobs Inc., a firm he founded in 1981.
Moskowitz graduated from [[Harvard University]] in 1969 with a Ph.D. in experimental psychology. Prior to that he graduated [[Queens College]] (New York), [[Phi Beta Kappa]], with degrees in [[mathematics]] and [[psychology]]. He has written/edited sixteen books, has published well over 300 articles and serves on the editorial board of major journals.
His latest book with co-author Alex Gofman, ''[[Selling Blue Elephants]]''<ref>{{cite book|last=Moskowitz|first=Howard|title=Selling Blue Elephants: How to make great products that people want BEFORE they even know they want them|year=2007|publisher=Pearson Prentice Hal|isbn=0136136680|url=https://www.amazon.com/Selling-Blue-Elephants-products-people/dp/0136136680/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1359826183&sr=1-1}}</ref> demonstrates and popularizes how IdeaMap (i-Novation`s flagship product) creates new products and messages... from areas as diverse as credit cards, jewelry offers, presidential messaging during election years, stock market communications, and trans-national innovation.
Moskowitz has won the Scientific Director`s Gold Medal for outstanding research at the [[U.S. Army Natick Laboratories]], and the 2001 and 2003 awards by [[ESOMAR]] (European Society Of Market Research). In 2004, Moskowitz was elected as an [[Institute of Food Technologists|IFT]] Fellow, and also was awarded the "David R. Peryam Award", from [[ASTM]], in recognition of outstanding contributions to the field of basic and applied sensory science.
In 2005, Moskowitz was awarded the [[Charles Coolidge Parlin]] Marketing Research Award for his substantial contributions and dedication to the advancement of marketing research practices. Most recently, he is the recipient of the [[Advertising Research Foundation|ARF]] Research Innovation Award and [[The Market Research Council]] Hall of Fame Award, both in 2006.
==Products== Moskowitz developed [[Dr. Pepper#Flavor variations|Cherry Vanilla Dr Pepper]] when he was hired in 2004 by [[Cadbury Schweppes]], which was hoping to expand the market for [[Dr. Pepper]] by developing a [[Product line extensions|product line extension]] using an alternative formulation with vanilla or cherry flavors. Moskowitz has been consulted by [[Campbell Soup]], [[General Foods]], [[Kraft Foods|Kraft]] and [[PepsiCo]] for his expertise in [[food optimization]]. According to Moskowitz he has optimized [[soup]]s, [[pizza]]s, [[salad dressing]]s, and [[Pickled cucumber|pickles]] in his work for various firms. His research on [[Prego]] [[spaghetti sauce]], which revealed a significant customer preference for an "extra-chunky" formulation, is notable as was his optimization of the amount of salt, sugar, and fat in spaghetti sauce at the "[[bliss point (food)|bliss point]]" which maximized consumer satisfaction. His first job after graduation from Harvard was for the [[United States Army]] with respect to [[Meal, Ready-to-Eat|Meals, Ready-to-Eat]], where he applied the concept of [[sensory-specific satiety]], the tendency for consumers to tire of strongly flavored foods, to ensure that the meals were formulated in a way that encouraged soldiers to eat sufficient calories.<ref name=NYTMag022013>{{cite news|title=The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/24/magazine/the-extraordinary-science-of-junk-food.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=March 1, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times Magazine|date=February 20, 2013|author=Michael Moss}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.mji-designlab.com/index.php?id=16&art=19&L=0 Moskowitz Jacobs Inc.: Executive Biographies] * [http://www.ted.com/talks/malcolm_gladwell_on_spaghetti_sauce.html TED Talk about Howard Moskowitz by Malcolm Gladwell, February 2004] * {{cite web|last=Gladwell|first=Malcolm|title=The Ketchup Conundrum|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/09/06/040906fa_fact_gladwell|publisher=The New Yorker|date=4 September 2004|accessdate=2 February 2013}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moskowitz, Howard}} [[Category:American marketing people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Market researchers]] [[Category:American food scientists]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Queens College, City University of New York alumni]] [[Category:American chief executives of food industry companies]]

{{about||the Kenyan long-distance runner|James Mwangi Macharia|other uses|Mwangi}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = James Mwangi | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = James Mwangi | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1962}} | birth_place = [[Kangema]], [[Kenya]] | nationality = Kenyan | alma_mater ='''[[University of Nairobi]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Commerce]])}}
'''[[Certified Public Accountant|Certified Public Accountant of Kenya]]'''
{{small|([[Certified Public Accountant]])}} | occupation = [[Accountant]], [[Banker|Bank Executive]], [[Businessman]] & [[Entrepreneur]] | years_active = 1993–present | home_town = [[Nairobi]] | spouse = 1 | title = [[Managing Director|Group Managing Director]] & [[CEO|Group CEO]]
[[Equity Group Holdings Limited]] }} '''James Njuguna Mwangi''' is an [[accountant]], [[banker]], [[businessman]] and [[entrepreneur]] in [[Kenya]], the largest economy in the [[East African Community]]. He is the current [[Managing Director|Group Managing Director]] and [[CEO|Group Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[Equity Group Holdings Limited]], the banking conglomerate with the largest customer base on the [[Africa]]n continent, in excess of 8 million as of 2014.{{cite web|title=Success Story of Equity Bank CEO, James Mwangi |last=Kwama |date=4 December 2013 |location=Nairobi |url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/kenyaat50/article/2000099368/success-story-of-equity-bank-ceo-james-mwangi?pageNo=1 | first=Kenneth| accessdate=21 October 2014|newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)]]}}{{cite web|title=Equity Bank of Kenya: Our History | url=http://www.equitybank.co.ke/index.php/about/our-history|date=|accessdate=21 October 2014|publisher=Equity Bank of Kenya|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020195326/http://www.equitybank.co.ke/index.php/about/our-history|archivedate=20 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} James Mwangi is also the current chairman{{Cite news|url=https://www.oxfordbusinessgroup.com/interview/obg-talks-james-mwangi-chairman-kenya-vision-2030-delivery-board|title=OBG talks to James Mwangi, Chairman, Kenya Vision 2030 Delivery Board|last=(http://www.hydrant.co.uk)|first=Site designed and built by Hydrant|date=2014-11-19|work=Oxford Business Group|access-date=2017-11-23|language=en}} of [[Kenya Vision 2030]] since 2009. ==Background and education== Mwangi was born in [[Kangema]], in [[Central Province (Kenya)|Kenya's Central Province]], circa 1962. His father was killed in the [[Mau Mau]] conflict, so the young Mwangi, together with his six siblings were raised by '''Grace Wairimu Mwangi''', their single mother. He attended ''Nyagatugu Primary School'' in Kangema Village. He went on to ''Ichagaki Secondary School'', on a government scholarship, having excelled in primary school. For his A-Level education, he went to ''Kagumo High School'', where he studied [[economics]], [[English literature]] and [[geography]]. He went on to the [[University of Nairobi]], graduating with the degree of [[Bachelor of Commerce]] (BCom). He also sat and passed the [[Certified Public Accountant|Certified Public Accountant of Kenya]] (CPA) examinations.{{cite web| url=http://www.kenyayetu.net/the-rise-and-rise-of-james-mwangi/| title=The Education History of James Mwangi|date=24 July 2012| accessdate=21 October 2014|publisher=KenyaYetu.Net|first=Craig| last=Rix}} ==Career== In 1993, in his capacity as "Finance Director", he was tasked by the Chairman and by the CEO of '''Equity Building Society''' (EBS), to wind up the insolvent organisation which was losing KSh5 million (approx. US$60,000 then), annually and had, at that time, accumulated total losses of KSh33 million (approx. US$380,000 then). However the young Mwangi, aged about 31 at the time, began by motivating the 27 staff members to give better customer care to the 27,000 customers they had then. He also encouraged them to use 25% of their salaries to buy EBS shares. When things began to brighten up at EBS, the society began to sell shares to customers and to pay annual dividends in 1997. In 2000, the society computerized their operations. They were able to raise more capital and attract more customers. On 31 August 2004, Equity Building Society became [[Equity Bank Kenya Limited|Equity Bank Kenya]]. In 2006, Equity Bank listed on the [[Nairobi Stock Exchange]] (NSE). On Thursday 18 June 2009, the Group's stock cross listed on the [[Uganda Securities Exchange]] and started trading that day, under the symbol: '''EBL'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/220/685424|title=Equity Bank Cross-Lists On USE|date=21 June 2009|accessdate=22 October 2014|first=Archive|last=Newvision|newspaper=[[New Vision]] (Kampala)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141021210134/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/220/685424|archivedate=21 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} {{asof|October 2014}}, the bank group has subsidiaries in [[Kenya]], [[Uganda]], [[Tanzania]], [[Rwanda]] and [[South Sudan]]. {{asof|March 2014}}, Equity Group Holdings Limited was a large financial services organisation in East Africa, with an asset base valued at over US$3.45 billion (KES:295 billion), with a total customer base in excess of 8.7 million, in the region the group serves.{{cite web|title=Equity Group In 20 Percent Profit Rise to Sh3.8 Billion| url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201404171408.html|publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM|Capital FM Online]] (Nairobi) via [[AllAfrica.com]]| first=Kennedy|last=Kangethe|date=17 April 2014|accessdate=22 October 2014}} ==Recent developments== James Mwangi is a married father of four sons. He and his wife own shares in the [[stock]] of Equity Group Holdings Limited and of British American Insurance Company Limited ([[Britam]]), making the family one of the wealthiest in Kenya. Their net worth was estimated at upward of US$170 million as at October 2014.{{cite web| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/James-Mwangi-fortune-in-Equity-Sh12bn/-/539552/2492394/-/item/0/-/13o1dnbz/-/index.html|title=Mwangi Family’s Fortune In Equity Tops KSh12 Billion| first=Victor|last=Juma|date=20 October 2014|accessdate=22 October 2014|newspaper=[[Nation Media Group|Business Daily Africa]] (Nairobi)}} ==Awards== In 2012 James Mwangi was named entrepreneur of the yearhttp://www.ey.com/gl/en/newsroom/news-releases/press-release_weoy_2012_winner by [[Ernst & Young]] in their [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award]] financial inclusion impact section. ==See also== *[[Equity Group Holdings Limited]] *[[List of African millionaires]] *[[List of wealthiest people in Kenya]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.equitybank.co.ke/ Webpage of Equity Bank Group] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mwangi, James}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kikuyu people]] [[Category:Kenyan accountants]] [[Category:Kenyan bankers]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox comics creator | name = Jerry Grandenetti | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|4|15}} | birth_place = [[Bronxville, New York|Bronxville]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|2|19|1926|4|15}} | death_place = [[East Patchogue, New York]], United States | nationality = American | area = Penciller, Inker | alias = | notable works = | awards = | subcat = American }} '''Charles J. "Jerry" Grandenetti'''<ref name=fft>{{cite web|authorlink=Frank Lovece |last=Lovece |first=Frank |url=http://filmfestivaltraveler.com/film-arts/42-features/964-rip-roy-lichtenstein-influence-jerry-grandenetti |title=RIP: Roy Lichtenstein Influence Jerry Grandenetti |work=Film Festival Traveler |date=September 29, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tDIyae1H?url=http://filmfestivaltraveler.com/index.php?option=com_content |archivedate=October 3, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> (April 15, 1926 – February 19, 2010)<ref name=fft /><ref>[https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/JTKF-Y5S Charles J. Grandenetti], [[Social Security Number]] 129-14-2175, at the [[Social Security Death Index]] via FamilySearch.org, retrieved on February 26, 2013; and [http://www.genealogybank.com/gbnk/ssdi/doc/ssdi/v1:12E26510CF34A788 via GenealogyBank.com], retrieved on September 27, 2013. [https://www.webcitation.org/6JxLqZqw0?url=http://www.genealogybank.com/gbnk/ssdi/doc/ssdi/v1:12E26510CF34A788 Archived] from the original on September 27, 2013.</ref> was an American [[comic book artist]] and advertising [[art director]], best known for his work with writer-artist [[Will Eisner]] on the celebrated comics feature "[[The Spirit]]", and for his decade-and-a-half run on many [[DC Comics]] [[war comics|war series]]. He also co-created the DC comic book ''[[Prez (comics)|Prez]]'' with [[Joe Simon]].
[[Pop artist]] [[Roy Lichtenstein]]'s 1962 drawing ''Jet Pilot'' is based on a Grandenetti comic-book panel on the cover of DC's ''[[All-American Comics|All-American Men of War]]'' #89 ([[cover-date]]d Feb. 1962), and Lichtenstein's 1964 triptych "[[As I Opened Fire]]" is based on panels by Grandenetti in "Wingmate of Doom" in issue #90 (April 1962).
==Biography==
===Early life and career=== [[Image:All-AmericanMenOfWar89.jpg|thumb|left|''All-American Men of War'' #89 (Feb. 1962). The lower-right panel is the source of [[Roy Lichtenstein]]'s 1962 drawing ''Jet Pilot''.]] Born in the village of [[Bronxville]] in the town of [[Eastchester, New York]], a suburb of New York City, Jerry Grandenetti studied art and architectural drawing at the Cartoonists and Illustrators School (later named the [[School of Visual Arts]]), in [[Manhattan]].<ref name="inter" /> He did World War II military service in the [[U.S. Navy]] "in 1942 or 1943", he recalled,<ref name="inter">Archive of Fears, Stephen. {{cite web|url=http://www.jergrand.com/interview.php |title="The Jerry Grandenetti Interview" |accessdate=2017-04-21 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514174207/http://www.jergrand.com/interview.php |archivedate=May 14, 2008 |df= }} at Grandenetti official site, n.d.</ref> and after the war attended [[Brooklyn]]'s [[Pratt Institute]] on the [[G.I. Bill]]. In either 1946 or 1948 (accounts differ), he was making the rounds of comic-book companies and met [[Everett M. "Busy" Arnold]], publisher of [[Quality Comics]]. Arnold had no position for him but sent Grandenetti to [[Will Eisner]], writer-artist of the Sunday-newspaper comic-book section starring Eisner's celebrated character the [[Spirit (comics)|Spirit]]. Grandenetti hired on as an art assistant. As ''[[The Comics Journal]]'' editor-publisher [[Gary Groth]] wrote, "By the late '40s, Eisner's participation in the strip had dwindled to a largely supervisory role. ... Eisner hired Jerry Grandenetti and [[Jim Dixon (comics)|Jim Dixon]] to occasionally ink his pencils. By 1950, [[Jules Feiffer|[Jules] Feiffer]] was writing most of the strips, and Grandenetti, Dixon, and [[Al Wenzel]] were drawing them",<ref>Archive of [[Gary Groth|Groth, Gary]], {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080429204530/http://www.tcj.com/267/e_groth.html |date=April 29, 2008 |title="Will Eisner: Chairman of the Board"|archivedate=2008 }},''The Comics Journal'' #267, May 2005. [http://www.tcj.com/267/e_groth.html Original site].</ref> with Grandenetti [[penciling]] as a [[ghostwriter|ghost-artist]], under Eisner's byline.<ref name="arndt"/>
"Working for Eisner was exciting", Grandenetti recalled in 2005. "Although there was no such thing as teaching or showing you how to develop your craft. ... Before [the feature's] demise he tried everything. Had me penciling 'The Spirit'. Later on it was [[Wally Wood]]", who drew it through to its end in 1952, "but nothing could save 'The Spirit'! Sad, too. It was probably the greatest comic strip ever created".<ref name="arndt">{{cite web|last=Arndt |first=Richard J. |url=http://www.enjolrasworld.com/Richard%20Arndt/The%20Warren%20Magazines%20Interviews.htm |title=The Warren Magazines: Interviews |date=February 3, 2010 |accessdate=13 March 2007 |archivedate=June 15, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313060303/http://www.enjolrasworld.com/Richard%20Arndt/The%20Warren%20Magazines%20Interviews.htm |df= }} Additional .</ref>
In 1949, Eisner, in his sideline as a comics packager, created the feature "Secret Files of Dr. Drew" for [[Fiction House]]. Grandenetti said Eisner instructed him to draw it "in the Eisner style. Which I did, badly. Anyway, after a couple of stories I began to do my own thing".<ref name="arndt" /> The eight-page story "The Strange Case of the Absent Floor" in ''Rangers Comics'' #47 (June 1949), which he both penciled and [[inker|inked]], marked Grandenetti's first credited comics art, and he remained on the feature (scripted by Eisner's office manager and future journalist [[Marilyn Mercer]]) through #60 (Aug. 1951). Grandenetti also drew "Senorita Rio" stories for the same publisher's ''Fight Comics''.<ref name=gcd>[http://www.comics.org/credit/name/Jerry%20Grandenetti/sort/chrono/ Jerry Grandenetti] at the [[Grand Comics Database]]</ref>
After doing a small amount of work for [[Lev Gleason Publications]]' ''Boy Comics'' #52 (April 1960), Media's ''Mister Universe'' #1 (July 1951), [[American Comics Group]]'s ''Adventures into the Unknown'' #22 (Aug. 1951), and [[Prize Comics]]' ''Black Magic'' vol. 2, #3 (Feb. 1952), Grandenetti began his 17-year run at [[DC Comics]].<ref name=gcd />
===DC Comics=== [[Image:OurFightingForces71.jpg|thumb|''Our Fighting Forces'' #71 (Oct. 1962): One of Grandenetti's wash-tone covers]] At DC, then the leading comic-book company and the home of [[Batman]] and [[Superman]], Grandenetti drew some of everything that was not a [[superhero]]. Beginning with ''[[Western Comics]]'' #27 (Sept. 1951), Grandenetti did [[Western comics]] (''[[All-Star Western]]''), [[crime fiction]] (''[[Racket Squad]] in Action'', ''[[Gang Busters]]'', ''[[Mr. District Attorney]]''), science fiction (''[[Strange Adventures]]''), and [[mystery fiction|mystery]]-suspense (''[[House of Mystery]]''), but made his mark as one of DC's signature [[war comics]] artists, drawing hundreds of [[anthological]] stories and covers in a dozen years' worth of such titles as ''[[All-American Men of War]]'', ''[[G.I. Combat]]'', ''[[Our Army at War]]'', ''[[Our Fighting Forces]]'', and ''[[Star Spangled War Stories]]''.<ref name=gcd />
DC war-comics editor and writer [[Robert Kanigher]] recalled that on the feature "Gunner and Sarge" in particular, Grandenetti "managed to get the grime and the humor of the two Marines (and, eventually their wonderful Pooch) fighting in the jungle as no one else could. Jerry liked to experiment and I had to sit on him to get him to stop it. Especially in his covers, which were outstanding, when I forced him to draw as realistically as possible".<ref>Robert Kanigher interview, ''The Comics'' (Oct. 1995)</ref> With Kanigher, Grandenetti co-created the feature "[[Mademoiselle Marie|Mlle. Marie]]", about a World War II [[French Resistance]] fighter, in ''Star Spangled War Stories'' #84 (Aug. 1959).<ref name=gcd /><ref>[http://www.toonopedia.com/mllemari.htm Mlle. Marie] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/62hbPk3iP?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/mllemari.htm Archived] October 25, 2011.</ref>
Grandenetti became known for cover art rendered in wash-tone, also known as grey-tone, which, as comics-art historian [[Don Mangus]] describes, "is executed as an ink-[[wash drawing]], and then a [[halftone]] [[Photostat]] of the cover is made, the logo added, and finally the color is laid in over this statted wash drawing",<ref name="mangus">{{cite web|last=Mangus |first=Don |url=http://www.comicartville.com/manguswoodconflict.htm |title=Conflict! |publisher=Comicartville.com |date=n.d. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sq0XOYtF?url=http://www.comicartville.com/manguswoodconflict.htm |archivedate=September 18, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> rendering a painted effect.
===Later comics career=== In late 1965, Grandenetti began freelancing for additional companies, drawing a small number of stories for [[Charlton Comics]] and [[Tower Comics]], and penciling a [[Sub-Mariner]] story—inked by the character's creator, [[Golden Age of comic books|Golden Age of Comics]] legend [[Bill Everett]]—in [[Marvel Comics]]' ''[[Tales to Astonish]]'' #86 (Dec. 1966).<ref name=gcd />
Mostly, however, Grandenetti began turning to [[Warren Publishing]], home of the black-and-white, [[horror fiction|horror]]-comics magazines ''[[Creepy (magazine)|Creepy]]'' and ''[[Eerie]]''. Grandenetti's work for Warren, writes comics-art historian Don Mangus, "returned to a much more expressionistic and experimental phase, building on what he had begun at Eisner's studio, or perhaps due to freedom from Kanigher’s restraints. Perhaps it was the subject matter or the fluid nature of the wash medium but whatever the case, he produced brilliant work at Warren in the late 1960s and early 1970s".<ref name="mangus" /> Warren would later reprint his youthful inking and background work for Will Eisner with the magazine series ''The Spirit''. Grandenetti was profiled in ''Creepy'' #42, and a [[self-portrait]] ran in ''Vampirella'' #16.
Concurrently, for DC, Grandenetti succeeded [[Neal Adams]] on the 1960s run of DC's [[supernatural]] spirit of vengeance the [[Spectre (comics)|Spectre]], drawing issues #6–10 (Oct. 1966 – June 1969). Grandenetti also helped revive the 1940s DC character the [[Phantom Stranger]], drawing the lead story in his return appearance in ''[[Showcase (comics)|Showcase]]'' #80 (Feb. 1969). In ''Showcase'' #82 (May 1969), he and writer [[Dennis O'Neil]] co-created the minor [[sword and sorcery]] character [[Nightmaster]]—originally assigned to then-newcomer [[Bernie Wrightson]], who was taken off it after his first seven pages proved disappointing.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.twomorrows.com/comicbookartist/articles/05wrightson.html |title=Like a Bat Out of Hell: Chatting with Bernie Wrightson, DC's Monster Maker |work=[[Comic Book Artist]] |publisher=[[Two Morrows Publishing]] |issue=5 |date=Summer 1999 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sq0rQnS4?url=http://www.twomorrows.com/comicbookartist/articles/05wrightson.html |archivedate=September 18, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
He contributed to at least one issue of the black-and-white humor magazine ''[[Sick (magazine)|Sick]]'' (#70, Oct. 1969), edited by his friend [[Joe Simon]], the Golden Age co-creator of [[Captain America]], then collaborated with Simon at DC on issues of ''Champion Sports''. The two then co-created the [[youth culture]] oddity ''[[Prez (comics)|Prez]]'', about the first teen president of the United States,<ref>{{cite book|last=McAvennie|first= Michael|last2=Dolan|first2=Hannah, ed.|chapter= 1970s|title = DC Comics Year By Year A Visual Chronicle|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]] |year=2010 |isbn= 978-0-7566-6742-9 |page= 156 |quote = Teenage President of the United States Prez Rickard didn't enjoy a long term in comics. However scripter Joe Simon and artist Jerry Grandenetti gave him plenty to tackle in four issues.}}</ref> and the one-episode misfire [[The Green Team (comics)|Green Team: Boy Millionaires]], in ''[[1st Issue Special]]'' #2 (May 1975). Grandenetti penciled a parody of the TV series ''[[Kolchak: The Night Stalker]]'' in the Marvel humor comic ''Arrgh!'' #4 (July 1975), for which he also drew the cover.<ref name=gcd />
Comics historian [[Mark Evanier]], calling Grandenetti "[o]ne of the great individual stylists of comic books in the fifties and sixties," wrote that, "As the [1960s] wore on, he got away from combat art and conventional page layouts, taking what he'd learned from [[Will Eisner|[Will] Eisner]] and applying it in new, then-revolutionary directions. Like most artists who departed from the conventional, his work was loved by many but disliked by some. … [B]y the early seventies, Grandenetti was working so far outside even the relaxed conventions of DC Comics that he no longer quite fit in. I thought he was a marvelous, distinct talent who wasn't precisely suited to the work he was assigned, like ''The Spectre'', ''Prez'' and "Nightmaster".<ref>{{cite web|authorlink=Mark Evanier |last=Evanier |first=Mark |url=http://www.newsfromme.com/archives/2003_11_12.html |title=Comic Artist Website of the Day |publisher="P.O.V. Online" |date=November 12, 2003 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x2eOgGRo?url=http://www.newsfromme.com/archives/2003_11_12.html |archivedate=March 8, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Grandenetti continued to freelance occasional stories for DC through at least ''G.I. Combat'' #270 (Oct. 1984).<ref name=gcd />
===Later life=== In 1990,<ref name="arndt" /> Grandenetti became an [[art director]] at the large [[advertising agency]] [[Young & Rubicam]]. Breaking into advertising, he recalled, "wasn't really [tough] because, unlike a lot of comic book illustrators, all of the time I had my eyes set elsewhere. I was developing that ability, while at the same time working for the comic book companies, by doing spot drawings and illustrations for small agencies. By the time I was ready, I had this well developed portfolio so I was able to break in".<ref name="inter" />
As of 2005, Grandenetti was freelancing for ad agencies in New York City, and doing [[fine art]] paintings in [[watercolor]], [[Acrylic paint|acrylics]], and [[mixed media]].
Grandenetti, who lived in [[Bellport, New York|Bellport]], New York, on [[Long Island]], died at age 83 at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in nearby [[East Patchogue, New York]]. The official cause of death was cardiopulmonary arrest, though he also had metastatic cancer.<ref name=fft />
==Legacy== [[Pop artist]] [[Roy Lichtenstein]]'s 1962 drawing ''Jet Pilot'' is based on a Grandenetti comic-book panel on the cover of DC's ''[[All-American Comics|All-American Men of War]]'' #89 (Feb. 1962).<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/deconstructing-roy-lichtenstein/40534730/ Deconstructing Lichtenstein], [http://www.lichtensteinfoundation.org/3163.htm The Roy Lichtenstein Foundation: ''Jet Pilot''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015051127/http://www.lichtensteinfoundation.org/3163.htm |date=October 15, 2007 }}.</ref> Lichtenstein's 1964 triptych "[[As I Opened Fire]]" is based on panels by Grandenetti in "Wingmate of Doom" in issue #90 (April 1962).<ref name=Waldman>{{cite book|first=Diane|last=Waldman| title= Roy Lichtenstein | publisher= [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] | page=104|chapter=War Comics, 1962–64|isbn= 0-89207-108-7}}</ref>
== References== {{Reflist |30em}}
==External links== *{{cite web|title=Jerry Grandenetti |publisher=Official site |url=http://www.jergrand.com/ |archivedate=June 22, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622182226/http://www.jergrand.com/ |deadurl=yes |df= }} *[http://lambiek.net/artists/g/grandenetti_jerry.htm Jerry Grandenetti] at the [[Lambiek Comiclopedia]].
