revision.text:
{{About|the multiple murderer|the economist of the University of Chicago|John A. List}} {{Infobox criminal | name = John List | image = Small ListMug.jpg | image_size = | caption = Mugshot of John List, c.2005 | birth_name = John Emil List | birth_date = {{Birth date|1925|09|17|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bay City, Michigan]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|03|21|1925|09|17|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Trenton, New Jersey]], U.S. | death_cause = Complications of [[pneumonia]] | nationality = American | other_names = Robert Peter "Bob" Clark | occupation = Accountant | criminal_charge = Five counts of [[first degree murder]] | penalty = Five consecutive life terms | conviction_status = Deceased | spouse = {{marriage|Helen List| December 1, 1951| November 9, 1971|reason=died}}
{{marriage|Delores Miller Clark|1985|1989|reason=divorced}} | children = {{Plainlist| * Patricia List * John List, Jr. * Frederick List }} | parents = John Frederick List (1859–1944)
Alma Hubinger List (1887–1971) | time_at_large = 17 years, 6 months, 23 days | date = November 9, 1971 | country = United States | locations = [[Westfield, New Jersey]] | targets = {{Plainlist| * Alma List * Helen List * Patricia List * John List, Jr. * Frederick List }} | fatalities = 5 | weapons = {{Plainlist| * [[9mm]] [[Steyr 1912|Steyr handgun]] * [[.22 LR|.22-caliber]] [[revolver]] }} | apprehended = June 1, 1989 | imprisoned = May 1, 1990 }} '''John Emil List''' (September 17, 1925 – March 21, 2008) was an American [[mass murder]]er{{cite web|url=https://www.crimemuseum.org/crime-library/serial-killers/serials-killers-vs-mass-murderers/|title=Serial Killers vs. Mass Murderers|publisher=[[National Museum of Crime & Punishment|Crime Museum]]|access-date=17 January 2018}} and long-time [[fugitive]]. On November 9, 1971, he killed his wife, mother, and three children in their home in [[Westfield, New Jersey|Westfield]], [[New Jersey]], then disappeared. He had planned the murders so that nearly a month passed before anyone suspected that anything was amiss. As he eluded justice for nearly 18 years, List assumed a new identity and remarried. He was finally apprehended in [[Virginia]] on June 1, 1989, after the story of his murders was broadcast on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] television program ''[[America's Most Wanted]]''. After [[extradition]] to New Jersey, he was [[Conviction (law)|convicted]] on five counts of [[first degree murder]] and [[Sentence (law)|sentenced]] to five consecutive terms of [[life imprisonment]] without [[parole]]. List gave critical financial problems, and his perception that his family was falling away from [[God]], as his rationale. Killing them, he allegedly reasoned, would assure their souls a place in [[Heaven]], where he hoped eventually to join them. He died in prison in 2008 at the age of 82. ==Personal background== Born in [[Bay City, Michigan|Bay City]], [[Michigan]], List was the only child of [[German-American]] parents, John Frederick List (1859–1944) and Alma Maria Barbara Florence (Hubinger) List (1887–1971). Like his father, he was a devout [[Lutheran]] and a [[Sunday school]] teacher. In 1943, he enlisted in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] and served in the infantry as a laboratory technician during [[World War II]]. After his discharge in 1946, he enrolled at the [[University of Michigan]] in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]], where he earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[business administration]] and a [[master's degree]] in [[accounting]], and was commissioned a [[second lieutenant]] through [[ROTC]].{{cite book|last=Ryzuk|first=Mary S.|year=1990|title=Thou Shalt Not Kill|publisher=Popular Library|isbn=0-445-21043-5|page=101}} In November 1950, as the [[Korean War]] escalated, List was recalled to active military service. At [[Fort Eustis]], in [[Virginia]], he met Helen Morris Taylor, the widow of an infantry officer [[killed in action]] in [[Korea]], who lived nearby with her daughter, Brenda. John and Helen married on December 1, 1951, in [[Baltimore]], and the family moved to northern [[California]] where List served as an Army accountant.Benford, T. ''Righteous Carnage: The List Murders in Westfield''. Scribner (1991), pp. 120-125. {{ISBN|0684192004}} After completion of his second tour in 1952, List worked for an accounting firm in [[Detroit]], and then as an audit supervisor at a paper company in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan|Kalamazoo]], where their three children were born.Benford 1991, pp. 126-7. By 1959, List had risen to general supervisor of the company's accounting department; but Helen, an [[alcoholism|alcoholic]], had become increasingly unstable.Benford 1991, pp. 131-7. In 1960, Brenda married and left the household, and List moved with the remainder of his family to [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], [[New York (state)|New York]], to take a job with [[Xerox]], where he eventually became director of accounting services.Benford 1991, pp. 137-9. In 1965, he accepted a position as vice president and comptroller at a bank in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]], [[New Jersey]], and moved with his wife, children, and mother into Breeze Knoll, a 19-room [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] mansion at 431 Hillside Avenue in [[Westfield, New Jersey|Westfield]].Benford 1991, pp. 153-60. ==Murders== On November 9, 1971, List methodically murdered his entire immediate family, using his own [[9mm]] [[Steyr 1912]] [[Semi-automatic pistol|semi-automatic handgun]]Benford TB, Johnson JP. ''Righteous Carnage: The List Murders in Westfield''. Scribner (1991), p. 117. and his father's [[Colt guns|Colt]] [[.22 caliber]] [[revolver]].Benford and Johnson, 1991, p. 285. While his children were at school he shot his wife Helen, 46, in the back of the head, and then his mother Alma, 84, above the left eye. As his daughter Patricia, 16, and younger son Frederick, 13, arrived home from school, he shot each of them in the back of the head. After making himself lunch, List drove to his bank to close his own and his mother's bank accounts, and then to Westfield High School to watch his elder son John Jr., 15, play in a [[soccer]] game. He drove the boy home, then shot him repeatedly in the chest and face.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/28/magazine/28List-t.html |title=Wanted: A Killer Disappears Into Another Life |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=December 28, 2008 | first=Elizabeth | last=McCracken | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Because his son tried to resist, List shot him repeatedly until he was sure the boy was dead. List placed the bodies of his wife and children on sleeping bags in the mansion's ballroom. He left his mother's body in her apartment in the attic. In a five-page letter to his pastor, found on the desk in his study, he wrote that he saw too much evil in the world, and he had killed his family to save their souls. He then cleaned the various crime scenes, carefully cut his own picture out of every family photograph in the house, tuned a radio to a religious station, and departed. The murders were not discovered until December 7, nearly a month later, due in part to the family's reclusiveness and refusal to socialize, and in part to notes sent by List to the children's schools and part-time jobs stating that the family would be visiting Helen's mother in [[North Carolina]] for several weeks. He also stopped milk, mail and newspaper deliveries. Neighbors noticed that all of the mansion's lights were illuminated day and night, with no apparent activity within. Finally, as the lights began burning out one by one, they called police.Ramsland, K: John List. [http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/family/list/1.html Crime Library]. Retrieved 26 September 2013. The case became the most notorious crime in New Jersey history since the kidnapping and murder of the [[Lindbergh baby]]. A nationwide [[Manhunt (law enforcement)|manhunt]] was launched. Police investigated hundreds of leads without success.Palm, Matthew (Writer), & Jacobson, Paul (Director). (1992). "To Save Their Souls" [Television series episode]. Wetzel, Stephanie (Producer), ''American Justice''. Los Angeles, Calif.: Entertainment Studios. All reliable photographs of List had been destroyed. The family car was found parked at [[John F. Kennedy Airport]] in [[New York City]], but there was no evidence that he had boarded a flight. Alma was flown to [[Frankenmuth, Michigan|Frankenmuth]], Michigan, and interred at the Saint Lorenz Lutheran Cemetery. Helen and her three children were buried at [[Fairview Cemetery (Westfield, New Jersey)|Fairview Cemetery]] in Westfield.Ramsland, K: John List. [http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/family/list/11.html Crime Library archive]. Retrieved 27 September 2013. Eighteen years later, on May 21, 1989, the murders were recounted on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] television program ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'', which at the time had been on the air less than a year.Notorious AMW Fugitive John List Dead at 82 (24 March 2008). [http://www.amw.com/features/feature_story_detail.cfm?id=2613 amw.com archive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222130610/http://www.amw.com/features/feature_story_detail.cfm?id=2613 |date=2012-02-22 }}. Retrieved 27 September 2013.John E. List, 82, Killer of 5 Family Members, Dies. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/nyregion/25list1.html?_r=0 The ''New York Times''], retrieved March 30, 2016. The broadcast featured an [[Age progression|age-progressed]] clay [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]], sculpted by [[forensic]] artist [[Frank Bender]], which turned out to bear a close resemblance to List's actual appearance.Fox, M (30 July 2011): Frank Bender, ‘Recomposer’ of Faces of the Dead, Dies at 70. [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/31/us/31bender.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 ''New York Times'' archive]. Retrieved 29 September 2013.[http://www.zimbio.com/John+List/articles/3Loc2nHVk3l/John+List+Bust+Remembered+Sculptor+Faces+Death John List Bust Remembered as Sculptor Faces Death - John List - Zimbio] List was located and arrested in Virginia less than two weeks after the episode was broadcast. ==Relocation, arrest and trial== In 1971, as the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] later discovered, List had traveled by train from New Jersey to Michigan, and then [[Colorado]]. He settled in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] in early 1972 and took an accounting job as Robert Peter "Bob" Clark, the name of one of his college classmates (although the real Bob Clark later asserted that he had never known List).{{Cite book|title = Death Sentence: The Inside Story of the John List Murders Joe Sharkey, Signet, 305 pp., {{ISBN|0-451-16947-6}}}} From 1979 to 1986 he was the comptroller at a paper box manufacturer outside Denver. He joined a Lutheran congregation and ran a car pool for shut-in church members. At one religious gathering, he met an Army [[Base Exchange|PX]] clerk named Delores Miller and married her in 1985. In February 1988, the couple moved to [[Midlothian, Virginia|Midlothian]], Virginia, where List, still using the name Bob Clark, resumed work as an accountant.Gross, Ken; Bonnett Sellinger, Margie; Kelley, Jack. [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20120566,00.html "In Hiding for 18 Years, a Wanted Man Is Caught by the Fbi and a Tv Posse"] ''People Magazine''. June 19, 1989. Retrieved May 4, 2015. On June 1, 1989, he was arrested at a [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] accounting firm after a Denver neighbor viewed the ''America's Most Wanted'' broadcast, recognized the profile, and alerted authorities.{{cite web |url=https://www.fbi.gov/richmond/about-us/history-1/history |title=FBI Richmond Division History |publisher=Federal Bureau of Investigation |accessdate=19 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116171738/http://www.fbi.gov/richmond/about-us/history-1/history |archivedate=16 November 2011 |df= }}Ryzuk, pp.396-399 He continued to stand by his alias for several months, even after [[extradition]] to [[Union County, New Jersey|Union County]], New Jersey, in late 1989; but finally, faced with irrefutable evidence—including a [[fingerprint]] match with List's military records, and then with evidence found at the crime scene—he confessed his true identity on February 16, 1990.Ryzuk, p.452He Just Fit Right In. [http://articles.philly.com/1989-06-11/news/26109127_1_law-officers-robert-p-clark-police-career Philly.com], retrieved March 30, 2016. At trial, List testified that he was faced with grave financial difficulties in 1971: he had lost his job at the Jersey City bank. To avoid sharing this humiliating development with his family, he spent each workday at the Westfield train station, reading newspapers until it was time to come home. He skimmed money from his mother's bank accounts to avoid defaulting on his [[mortgage]]. He was also dealing with his wife's alcoholism and her untreated [[syphilis#tertiary|tertiary syphilis]], contracted from her first husband and concealed for 18 years. According to trial testimony, Helen had pressured List into marriage by falsely claiming that she was pregnant, then insisted that they marry in [[Maryland]], which does not require blood testing to obtain a marriage license.Benford 1991, pp. 125-30. Though her health progressively worsened, she said nothing to List or her physicians until 1969, when a check-up revealed the condition. By then the disease and her excessive alcohol consumption had, according to testimony, "transformed her from an attractive young woman to an unkempt and paranoid recluse"[http://www.goleader.com/list/ The List Murders Stun Westfield In 1971] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060321184241/http://www.goleader.com/list/ |date=2006-03-21 }} By Kathy Halverson, February 17, 2001 For The Westfield Leader and The Times. Accessed June 28, 2007{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE0DE1630F934A35757C0A966958260 |title=Slaying Suspect Saw 2 Choices, Doctor Testifies |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=April 7, 1990 | first=Joseph F. | last=Sullivan | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} who frequently—and often publicly—disparaged List, comparing his sexual skills unfavorably with those of her first husband.Benford 1991, pp. 130-35. A court-appointed psychiatrist testified that List suffered from [[obsessive-compulsive personality disorder]], and that he saw only two solutions to his situation: accept [[Social programs in the United States#Welfare|welfare]] or kill his family and send their souls to [[Heaven]].{{cite news |title=I Know That What Has Been Done Is Wrong |date=1990 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/nyregion/i-know-that-what-has-been-done-is-wrong.html |work=New York Times |accessdate=March 30, 2016 }} Welfare was an unacceptable option, he reasoned, because it would expose him and his family to ridicule and violate his [[Authoritarian personality|authoritarian]] father's teachings regarding the care and protection of family members. On April 12, 1990, List was convicted of five counts of [[first degree murder]]. At his sentencing hearing he denied direct responsibility for his actions: "I feel that because of my mental state at the time, I was unaccountable for what happened. I ask all affected by this for their forgiveness, understanding and prayer."{{cite news |author=Associated Press |date=May 20, 1990 |title=Judge Sentences Family Killer to Life in Prison |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-05-02/news/mn-174_1_life-sentences |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=26 September 2013 }} The judge was unpersuaded: "John Emil List is without remorse and without honor," he said. "After 18 years, five months and 22 days, it is now time for the voices of Helen, Alma, Patricia, Frederick and John F. List to rise from the grave." He imposed a sentence of five terms of [[life imprisonment]], to be served consecutively, the maximum permissible penalty at the time.{{cite news |title=Killer of Family Gets 5 Life Terms : Court: Judge sentences accountant who murdered his mother, wife and children 18 years ago to the maximum sentence |author=AP |date=May 11, 1990 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-05-01/news/mn-423_1_maximum-sentence |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=September 9, 2014 }} List filed an appeal of his convictions on grounds that his judgment had been impaired by [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] due to his military service. He also argued that the letter he left behind at the crime scene, essentially his confession, was a confidential communication to his pastor and therefore inadmissible as evidence. A federal appeals court rejected both arguments.{{cite news |last=Stout |first=D. |date=March 25, 2008 |title=John E. List, 82, Killer of 5 Family Members, Dies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/nyregion/25list1.html |work=NY Times |accessdate=26 September 2013 }} List later expressed a degree of remorse for his crimes: "I wish I had never done what I did," he said. "I've regretted my action and prayed for forgiveness ever since."List and Goodrich (2006): ''Collateral Damage: The John List Story'', p. 80. When asked by [[Connie Chung]] in 2002 why he had not taken his own life, he said he believed that [[suicide]] would have barred him from Heaven, where he hoped to be reunited with his family. ==Death== List died of complications from [[pneumonia]] at age 82 on March 21, 2008, while in prison custody at [[St. Francis Medical Center (Trenton, New Jersey)|St. Francis Medical Center]] in [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], New Jersey.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/25/nyregion/25list1.html?em&ex=1206590400&en=54ef92d43724f8e2&ei=5087%0A |title=John E. List, 82, Killer of 5 Family Members, Dies |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=March 25, 2008 | first=David | last=Stout | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} In reporting his death, the [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] ''[[Star-Ledger]]'' referred to him as "the bogeyman of Westfield."[http://blog.nj.com/njv_mark_diionno/2008/03/the_bogeyman_of_westfield_a_gh.html "The bogeyman of Westfield, a ghost story that won't end" by Mark Di Ionno, The Star Ledger] ==Home arson== Breeze Knoll was destroyed by [[arson]] on August 20, 1972, approximately 10 months after the murders. The crime remains officially unsolved.Breeze Knoll: The John List Murder House. [http://www.house-crazy.com/breeze-knoll-the-john-list-murder-house/ house-crazy.com], retrieved December 29, 2015. Destroyed along with the home was the ballroom's [[stained glass]] skylight, rumored to be a signed [[Louis Comfort Tiffany|Tiffany]] original, worth at least $100,000 at the time ({{Inflation|US|100000|1972|r=-4|fmt=eq}}). A new house was built on the site in 1974. ==In popular culture== Over the years, List and his crimes have furnished inspiration for a number of movies and documentaries. Examples include the 1993 film ''[[Judgment Day: The John List Story]]'', in which List was portrayed by [[Robert Blake (actor)|Robert Blake]]; the 1987 film ''[[The Stepfather (1987 film)|The Stepfather]]'' and its [[The Stepfather (2009 film)|2009 remake]];{{cite news|last=Ryan|first=Desmond|title=How Profitable Sequels Succeed: They Just Bring 'em Back Alive|url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-12-03/entertainment/26158069_1_stepfather-mortal-coil-predator-ii|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=December 3, 1989}} and the character [[Keyser Söze]] in the 1995 film ''[[The Usual Suspects]]''.''The Usual Suspects'' DVD commentary featuring [[Bryan Singer]] and [[Christopher McQuarrie]], [2000]. Retrieved 27 September 2002 A 1996 episode of the series ''[[Forensic Files]]'' discussed the List murders.{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1469600/ | series=[[Forensic Files]] | title=The List Murders | date=December 12, 1996}} A 2003 episode of the [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] series ''[[American Justice]]'' also detailed the case and featured an interview with List.{{cite web | url=http://www.tv.com/shows/american-justice/to-save-their-souls-819731/ | series=[[American Justice]] | title=To Save Their Souls | date=February 12, 2003}} In 1972, List was proposed as a suspect in the [[D. B. Cooper]] [[air piracy]] case because of the timing of his disappearance (two weeks prior to the airline hijacking), multiple matches to the hijacker's description, and the reasoning that "a fugitive accused of mass murder has nothing to lose".{{cite news| title = D.B. Cooper: A Timeline | work = [[New York (magazine)|New York]] | last = Coreno | first = Catherine | date = October 22, 2007 | url = http://nymag.com/news/features/39617/ | accessdate = January 10, 2008}}{{cite book |last1=Benford |first1=Timothy B. |last2=Johnson |first2=James P. | title = Righteous Carnage: The List Murders in Westfield | publisher = iUniverse | year= 2000 | location = [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | pages = 76–77 | isbn = 0-595-00720-1 }} List was questioned by FBI investigators after his capture, but he denied any involvement in the Cooper case. While his name is still occasionally mentioned in Cooper articles and documentaries, no direct evidence implicates him, and the FBI no longer considers him a suspect. In 2008, [[John Walsh (television host)|John Walsh]], the host of ''America's Most Wanted'', donated the age-progressed bust by Frank Bender that played a pivotal role in List's apprehension to a forensic science exhibit at the now defunct [[National Museum of Crime & Punishment]] in [[Washington, DC]]. In 2015, the story was covered in Season 2, Episode 2 of the [[Investigation Discovery]] show, ''[[Your Worst Nightmare]].'' The episode was named "Murder House" and premiered on November 18, 2015.{{cite web | url=https://www.investigationdiscovery.com/tv-shows/your-worst-nightmare/ | series=[[Your Worst Nightmare]] | title=Murder House | date=November 18, 2015}} ==See also== ===Similar cases=== [[Dupont de Ligonnès murders and disappearance|Xavier Dupont de Ligonnès]], a [[France|French]] man suspected of murdering his wife and four children in April 2011. They were found buried under the back patio of the family home in [[Nantes]]. In the following days, Xavier was caught on CCTV staying at several hotels in different parts of France using a fake name, before disappearing. No trace of him has ever been found. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * ''Righteous Carnage: The List Murders'' Timothy B. Benford and James P. Johnson, iUniverse, 332 pp., {{ISBN|0-595-00720-1}} * ''Death Sentence: The Inside Story of the John List Murders'' Joe Sharkey, Signet, 305 pp., {{ISBN|0-451-16947-6}} * ''Collateral Damage: The John List Story '' John E. List and Austin Goodrich, iUniverse, Inc., 130pp., {{ISBN|0-595-39536-8}} * ''Thou Shalt Not Kill'' Mary S. Ryzuk, Warner Books, 509pp., {{ISBN|0-445-21043-5}} ==External links== {{Portal|New Jersey|Biography|Crime}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060321184241/http://www.goleader.com/list/ Newspaper articles on John List] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050711080638/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/family/list/1.html John List, famous murder - The Crime Library] * {{Find a Grave|25511539|name=John Emil List}} * {{IMDb title|0401220|American Justice Episode #169: To Save Their Souls}} {{Stepfather series}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List, John}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American criminals]] [[Category:1971 murders in the United States]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:American Lutherans]] [[Category:American mass murderers]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American murderers of children]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:American people who died in prison custody]] [[Category:American prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:American prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment]] [[Category:Burials in Michigan]] [[Category:Criminals from Michigan]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Familicides]] [[Category:Filicides]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in New Jersey]] [[Category:Matricides]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by New Jersey]] [[Category:People extradited within the United States]] [[Category:People from Bay City, Michigan]] [[Category:People from Westfield, New Jersey]] [[Category:People with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by New Jersey]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in New Jersey detention]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:People from Midlothian, Virginia]]

may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_penalty = | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | footnotes = }}
'''Jacob "Kobi" Alexander''' (born May 4, 1952) is an Israeli-American businessman. He is the founder and the former [[CEO]] of [[New York City|New York]]-based [[Comverse Technology]]. In 2006, he was charged with multiple counts of [[fraud]] and related offenses pertaining to irregularities in trading of Comverse stock; he subsequently fled to [[Namibia]], a nation which has no [[extradition treaty]] with the US.
Alexander founded Comverse Technology (NASDAQ: CMVT) in 1982 and built it up from a 3-person Israeli startup to employing over 5,000, becoming the leading provider of software and systems for telecommunication companies worldwide. Comverse's success led to its inclusion in the NASDAQ 100 and S&P 500 indices.
==Early life==
Alexander was born on May 4, 1952, into a middle-class family in [[Kfar Saba]], [[Israel]]. His mother was a school teacher, and his father an officer in the signal corps of the [[Israeli Defense Forces]], and later, the Managing Director of the Israeli National Oil Company.
Following military service, Alexander enrolled in the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], receiving a BA in Economics ''magna cum laude'' in 1977. In 1978 he traveled to the United States earning an MBA at [[New York University]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}}
In his early years in New York, he met an electrical engineer and together with his brother in law, a professor of Computer Science at Columbia University, the three conceived voice mail technology and developed the idea of what was to become Comverse Technology. The founders understood already then that communications will be a big market, and pioneered the voice mail systems that today are used by telecoms worldwide to support telephony services.
==Career== {{Update | section | date = October 2016 | inaccurate = yes}} In 1981, fresh with his NYU MBA, Alexander returned to Israel to bootstrap Comverse. In 1986, after struggling for over 4 years with the company reaching the brink of bankruptcy, the two other founders left their operational roles, and subsequently left the company.
Upon taking the helm, Alexander made three key strategic decisions: # Selling strictly to telecoms, who in turn represented hundreds of thousands of end user licenses for Comverse systems, and who enabled Comverse to piggyback on their growth. # Focusing on markets outside the U.S. where competition was weaker, enabling Comverse to establish leadership in certain regions early on. # Raising financing when market conditions were favorable.
Within a short amount of time, Comverse was back on its feet. A major breakthrough came when Alexander convinced Swiss telecom giant Ascom to invest US$6 million in the company in the mid 1980s, providing Comverse the capital it needed at that time. In 1986, Alexander was able to take Comverse public on the [[NASDAQ]].
In 1997, Comverse bought its main competitor for US$700 million, at the time the largest acquisition to date for an Israeli-based company. Comverse Technology, Inc., which owns 100% of Comverse, also owns majority equity in several other companies, including [[Verint Systems|Verint]] and Ulticom. It has over US$1.5 billion in sales to over 450 telecoms in 120 countries supporting more than 450 million subscribers worldwide. As of March 2006, the company employed approximately 6000 people in over 50 countries, had a market capitalization of approximately US$6 billion, and over US$2.2 billion in cash.
Alexander also formerly owned 25% of the Israeli basketball team [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themarker.com/misc/1.114884|title=Kobi Alexander, Elite Industries selling holdings in Maccabi Tel Aviv|work=TheMarker|access-date=2017-07-18|language=he}}</ref>
==Awards and accomplishments==
For his achievements over the last 25 years, Alexander received the several business awards. He came 12th in Chief Executive Magazine's: "Market Value Added Ranking" of the CEOs of the 1000 largest US corporations, ranking those that "created the most wealth for shareholders".{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} The successes of Alexander and Comverse were recognized by the world's leading publications including Barron's, Bloomberg, Business Week, Financial World, Forbes, Fortune, International Business, and Wall Street Journal.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Alexander was awarded "Entrepreneur of the Year" by both Ernst & Young and Deloitte & Touche.
The Wall Street Transcript, naming Kobi Alexander as the Gold Award Winner in the Computer Telephony industry said: "... an exceptional management team have yielded consistently outstanding revenues, earnings, and shareholder value. Alexander has set some very high standards for this company and this industry."{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
[[File:Comverse Logo.jpg|thumb|Comverse]] In addition to Comverse Technology, Alexander spun off and took public several other companies including Ulticom (NASDAQ: ULCM) and [[Verint Systems]] (NASDAQ: VRNT). Companies under his leadership were listed in Barron's 500, Business Week: "Hot Growth Companies", "Business Week 50", Business Week: "The Information Technology 100", Financial World: "America's Best 100 Growth Companies", Fortune: "100 Fastest Growing Companies"',<ref>{{cite news | url = http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2000/09/04/286829/index.htm | publisher = Fortune | work = Ten Stocks: The Best Of The Bunch | title = Betting on high-growth companies is scary. We've tried to make it safer, by finding ten stocks that can sustain a long and, yes, explosive run. | first=David | last=Rynecki | date=September 4, 2000}}</ref> International Business: "100 Fastest-Growing International Companies", Wall Street Journal: "10-Year Best Performers", and Wall Street Journal "Honor Roll", among others. In 2006, Comverse was named one of Institutional Investor: America's Most Shareholder-Friendly Companies". "As CEO of Comverse, Alexander was sought out by the likes of former Chinese President [[Jiang Zemin]], who slipped away from official meetings in 2000 and steered his motorcade through a pot-holed section of Tel Aviv to meet with him."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://quote.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aJHBHVHTD2JE |work=Bloomberg |title=Former Comverse Chief Alexander Arrested in Namibia (Update8) |date=September 27, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930035232/http://quote.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aJHBHVHTD2JE |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }}</ref> He served as the [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of CTI from 1987 to May 1, 2006, when he resigned during an investigation being conducted by a Special Committee of CTI's [[Board of Directors]] into the timing of CTI's [[stock option]] grants. He was Chairman of several CTI subsidiaries, including [[Verint Systems]] and Ulticom.
==Criminal charges== On July 31, 2006, Alexander was charged by [[United States Department of Justice]] authorities with multiple charges of [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] to commit various types of [[fraud]] (including [[securities fraud]], [[wire fraud]] and [[mail fraud]]), as well as with related offences, all relating to the timing of Comverse's stock option grants.
After Alexander left the [[United States]] on June 21, 2006 on a pre-planned annual vacation in Israel,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.namibian.com.na/2006/October/national/064DD41C82.html | publisher = The Namibian | title = A US fugitive, a Namibian brigadier and dollars galore | author = Werner Menges | date = 2006-10-03 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> his lawyers arranged with American authorities that he would return to face [[indictment]] on July 30, 2006; however, he instead traveled to [[Germany]]. On July 31 a warrant was issued for his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fbi.gov/wanted/alert/alexander_j.htm |title=Jacob Alexander |work=Crime Alert |publisher=[[FBI]] |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010092026/http://www.fbi.gov/wanted/alert/alexander_j.htm |archivedate=October 10, 2006 }}</ref>
On August 9, 2006 the [[United States Securities and Exchange Commission]] filed a civil injunctive action in the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] against Alexander, along with alleged co-conspirators [[William F. Sorin]], Comverse's former Senior General Counsel, and [[David Kreinberg]], Comverse's former [[Chief Financial Officer]]. The complaint makes nine claims of violation of the [[Securities Act]] and the [[Securities Exchange Act of 1934|Exchange Act]], including fraud (First and Second Claims), and falsification of books, records or accounts (Fourth Claim). Through this action, the Commission is seeking [[permanent injunction|permanent injunctive relief]], disgorgement of ill-gotten gains, civil damages, and a prohibition against any of the defendants becoming officers of a securities-issuing entity under SEC jurisdiction.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
Alexander transferred over 40 million dollars from his personal U.S. bank account to his personal bank account in Israel. He was arrested by [[Interpol]] in [[Windhoek, Namibia]] on September 27, 2006. He was released on bail on October 3, 2006.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.zdnet.com/2100-3513_22-6120521.html?part=rss&tag=feed&subj=zdnn | title = Ex-Comverse CEO arrested in Namibia | publisher = [[ZDNet]] | date = 2006-09-27 | author = [[Reuters]] }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/5386276.stm | title = Fugitive US tycoon held in Africa | date = 2006-09-27 | work = Business news | publisher = [[BBC]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aJHBHVHTD2JE&refer=news | publisher = Bloomberg | title = Former Comverse Chief Alexander Arrested in Namibia | date = 2006-09-27 | author = Bob Van Voris }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.namibian.com.na/2006/September/national/064CE75EFB.html |publisher=The Namibian |title=Namibia swoops on one of FBI's 'most wanted' suspects |author=Werner Menges |date=2006-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609193414/http://www.namibian.com.na/2006/September/national/064CE75EFB.html |archivedate=2007-06-09 |df= }}</ref> According to a Reuters report of April 23, 2007, the Namibian government described Alexander as "very passionate" about the country and its people; Alexander has promised to boost academic interest in science and technology in Namibia by establishing an annual scholarship for primary and secondary level students.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSL2324973420070423 | work=Reuters | title=Wanted U.S. millionaire starts Namibia student fund | date=April 23, 2007}}</ref> He has also begun to introduce advanced technology to the country with his development of a low budget solar powered housing project for 100 low-income Namibian families.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3349589,00.html|title=Alexander invests in Namibia poor|date=2007-08-01|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref>
Despite fighting extradition to the United States, Alexander announced on January 28, 2008 that he has filed suit against Comverse. Alexander claims the firm owes him $72 million in severance, unexercised stock options, and bonus pay.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNews/idUSN2849022420080128 | title = UPDATE 1-Kobi Alexander sues Comverse for more than $72 mln | accessdate = 2008-02-11 | author = Reuters | authorlink = Reuters | date = 2008-01-28}}</ref>
On July 3, 2008 a Namibian court split decisions for and against Alexander granting his request to remove the judge currently assigned to preside at his extradition hearing while declining to assign a magistrate of his choosing. Additionally, the Namibian High Court did not, at Alexander's attorneys' request, rule unconstitutional the Extradition Act which would allow Alexander to be imprisoned at some point during the upcoming extradition hearing.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601116&sid=aBFAfZ0XV3pw&refer=africa | work=Bloomberg | title=Namibia Court Rules in Favor of 'Kobi' Alexander, Namibian Says | date=July 3, 2008}}</ref> As reported by Bloomberg.com on November 19, 2008 a hearing to request Alexander's extradition to the United States was postponed until March 4, 2009 pending Alexander's appeal to Namibia's Supreme Court regarding which judge should hear the case. This appeal, not yet scheduled, will likely be adjudicated in March or April 2009.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601116&sid=aLf8q31Iufb8&refer=africa | work=Bloomberg | title='Kobi' Alexander Wins Delay of Extradition Hearing to June 9 | date=March 4, 2009}}</ref> The final outcome of the extradition proceedings can be several years away pending the appeals process.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ah_z8Ls5skJA | work=Bloomberg | title=Kobi Alexander's Extradition for Fraud May Take Years (Update1) | date=October 5, 2006}}</ref> Despite impending extradition proceedings, Alexander has invested heavily within the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com.na/content/view/435/33/ |title=Kobi Alexander put aside funds for local students |accessdate=2007-11-04 |author=The Namibia Economist |publisher=[[Namibia Economist]] |date=2007-04-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218175126/http://www.economist.com.na/content/view/435/33/ |archivedate=2007-12-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2011, Alexander settled the civil charges with the SEC and gave up bank accounts worth $46 million to federal authorities.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/money-gallery/2011-12-30/slideshow-the-top-sec-settlements-of-2011.html#slide17 | work=Bloomberg | title=The Biggest Payouts}}</ref>
On Aug 22, 2016 it was reported by Scott Cohn on [[CNBC]] that Alexander will return to the US to face criminal charges.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/08/22/fugitive-comverse-ceo-kobi-alexander-will-return-to-us-to-face-charges.html|title=Decade later, indicted CEO Kobi Alexander will return to US to face charges|last=Cohn|first=Scott|date=Aug 22, 2016|work=CNBC}}</ref> On February 23, 2017, Judge Nicholas Garaufis of the Eastern District of New York, sentenced Alexander to 30 months in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/crime/former-ceo-of-li-software-firm-comverse-sentenced-to-30-months-1.13167015|title=Comverse ex-CEO Jacob 'Kobi' Alexander sentenced to 30 months}}</ref> On March 1, 2018, Alexander was transferred to Israel to carry out his remaining sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Kobi-Alexander-Comverse-founder-and-convict-is-on-his-way-to-Israel-543957|title=KOBI ALEXANDER, COMVERSE FOUNDER AND CONVICT, IS ON HIS WAY TO ISRAEL}}</ref>
In October, 2018 it was reported that he had recently been released from prison.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20181020034855/https://www.haaretz.com/misc/article-print-page/.premium.MAGAZINE-israel-s-cyber-spy-industry-aids-dictators-hunt-dissidents-and-gays-1.6573027 Revealed: Israel's cyber-spy industry helps world dictators hunt dissidents and gays], Hagar Shezaf, Jonathan Jacobson, Oct. 19, 2018, [[Haaretz]]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{USGovernment|sourceURL=https://www.sec.gov/litigation/complaints/2006/comp19796.pdf}}
==Further reading== *{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB114265075068802118 |title=The Perfect Payday: Some CEOs reap millions by landing stock options when they are most valuable. Luck—or something else? |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=March 18, 2006 |first=Charles |last=Forelle |first2=James |last2=Bandler }}

{{Infobox person |name = Konrad Bernheimer |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Konrad Otto Bernheimer |birth_date = {{bda|1950|08|30|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Rubio, Venezuela|Rubio]], Venezuela |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = German |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = art dealer and collector |education = |alma_mater = |occupation = chairman and owner, [[Bernheimer Fine Old Masters]], Munich
former owner, [[Colnaghi]], London |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Barbara Schaeffer |partner = |children = |parents = Kurt Bernheimer
Mercedes Uzcátegui Ramírez |relations = [[Otto Bernheimer]] (grandfather)
[[Lehmann Bernheimer]] (great grandfather) |website = }} '''Konrad Otto Bernheimer''' (born 30 August 1950) is a German art dealer and collector. He is the chairman and owner of [[Bernheimer Fine Old Masters]] in Munich, and was the owner of [[Colnaghi]] in London. He sold Colnaghi to the Spanish dealers [[Jorge Coll]] and Nicolas Cortés in 2016. ==Early life== Konrad Otto Bernheimer was born in [[Rubio, Venezuela|Rubio]], Venezuela, on 30 August 1950.{{cite book|title=Club Carriere – Enzyklopädie des Erfolges März 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kLqWwDs7v4IC&pg=PT387|accessdate=27 November 2015|year=2004|publisher=Algoprint Verlags AG|isbn=978-3-9522689-1-9|page=387}}{{cite web|title=P & D Colnaghi & Co Ltd|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/03697496/officers|website=Companies House|accessdate=20 November 2015}} Following [[Kristallnacht]] on 9–10 November 1938, which saw the huge plate glass windows of the [[Bernheimer-Haus]] smashed, the family was sent to [[Dachau concentration camp]]. The Mexican government intervened, as his grandfather [[Otto Bernheimer]] was the Mexican honorary consul in Munich. [[Hermann Göring]], a Bernheimer client, did a deal whereby they bought his niece’s Venezuelan coffee plantation which was struggling, and were allowed to emigrate there, and also had to take Göring's aunt and her Jewish husband along, and support them until they died.{{cite news|last1=Gleadell|first1=Colin|title=Art Sales: Bernheimer clears out|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/art/89883/art-sales-bernheimer-clears-out.html|accessdate=20 November 2015|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=3 November 2015}} His father Kurt Bernheimer (1911–1954) committed suicide (which Konrad only found out about when writing his memoirs) in Venezuela, and his Venezuelan mother, Mercedes Uzcátegui Ramírez, and his two sisters joined Otto in Germany, who had returned to Munich in 1945. ==Career== [[File:München Lenbachplatz Haus Bernheimer.jpg|thumb|Bernheimer-Haus]] Konrad O. Bernheimer is the fourth generation of a family dealing in art and antiques, founded by his great-grandfather [[Lehmann Bernheimer]] as ''Bernheimer'' in May 1864.{{cite web|title=Konrad Bernheimer|url=http://www.colnaghi.co.uk/konrad-bernheimer|website=colnaghi|accessdate=20 November 2015}} Bernheimer took over the family business in 1977, aged 26, and has moved it from a more broadly based art and antiques business to one dealing in Old Masters.{{cite news|title=Dealer's dynasty: Konrad Bernheimer, Chairman of Pictura at TEFAF, is the fourth generation of a family of distinguished dealers. He talks to Susan Moore about his firm's extraordinary history.|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Dealer's+dynasty%3A+Konrad+Bernheimer,+Chairman+of+Pictura+at+TEFAF,+is...-a0196382942|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=Apollo Magazine|date=1 March 2009}} In 1987, he sold the [[Bernheimer-Haus]] in Munich, a "massive baroque-style, purpose-built palace ten bays wide and six storeys high". As well as being the chairman and owner of [[Bernheimer Fine Old Masters]], Munich, he owned [[Colnaghi]] in London, founded in 1760, and the world's oldest gallery, which he bought in 2002. He sold the company to the Spanish dealers [[Jorge Coll]] and Nicolas Cortés in 2016. {{cite web|title=150 Years of Bernheimer Anniversary Exhibition|url=http://www.bernheimer.com/photography/en/exhibition/811/150-years-of-bernheimer-anniversary-exhibition|website=bernheimer}} He is a board member of [[The European Fine Art Fair|The European Fine Art Foundation]], and chairman of its fine art division, Pictura, since 2004. ==Publications== * ''Great Masters and Unicorns'' (2015){{cite web|url=https://www.apollo-magazine.com/the-secret-lives-of-the-great-art-dealers/|title=The secret lives of the great art dealers - Apollo Magazine|date=27 June 2016|website=apollo-magazine.com|accessdate=14 December 2017}} ==Personal life== [[File:Marquartstein Castle North-West View.jpg|thumb|Burg Marquartstein, 2009]] He owns the 11th century 40-bedroom castle, [[Burg Marquartstein]] in [[Marquartstein]], Bavaria, which is listed for sale with [[Sotheby's International Realty]] as of November 2015, with "price upon request".{{cite web|title=Burg Marquartstein|url=http://www.sothebysrealty.com/eng/sales/detail/180-l-3597-5bpy5n/a-genuine-rarity-a-romantic-castle-in-a-prime-location-on-the-edge-of-the-alps-other-bavaria-bv-83250|website=sothebysrealty|accessdate=20 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120120407/http://www.sothebysrealty.com/eng/sales/detail/180-l-3597-5bpy5n/a-genuine-rarity-a-romantic-castle-in-a-prime-location-on-the-edge-of-the-alps-other-bavaria-bv-83250|archivedate=20 November 2015|df=}} The Bernheimer sale of works of art from Burg Marquarstein at [[Sotheby's]] in London in November 2015 realised £2,371,000.{{cite web|title=Bernheimer Day Sale|url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/2015/bernheimer-day-sale-l15043.html|website=Sotheby's|accessdate=27 November 2015}} His daughter Blanca Bernheimer has dealt in fine art photography since 2005. ==Honours== Bernheimer has been awarded the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]]. and he is Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres de la Republique Française. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bernheimer, Konrad}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bernheimer family|Konrad]] [[Category:German art collectors]] [[Category:German art dealers]] [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]]

{{Infobox person |name = Lina Ashar |image = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] |publisher= |residence = [[Mumbai]], [[India]] |nationality = Indian |alma_mater = [[Victoria College, Melbourne]] |occupation = [[Chairman]], Kangaroo Kids Education Limited |relations = |awards = Lifetime Award for Achievement in Education (2014)
Alumni Excellence Award (2015)
Inspiring Business Leaders India Award (2016) }} '''Lina Ashar''' is an Indian [[educationist]], [[entrepreneur]], and [[writer]] based in [[Mumbai]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Meet Edupreneur Lina Ashar – The founder of Kangaroo Kids Preschool |url=https://www.inventiva.co.in/2017/08/meet-edupreneur-lina-ashar-founder-kangaroo-kids-preschool/|accessdate=|publisher=Inventiva|date=26 August 2017}} She is the [[chairperson]] of Kangaroo Kids Education Limited (KKEL), an education chain that runs the schools.{{cite news|last1=Nair Anand|first1=Shilpa |title=On a different path|url=https://www.thehindu.com/features/education/school/on-a-different-path/article5032215.ece|accessdate=|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|date=18 August 2013}} She is also the [[Organizational founder|founder]] of [[Kangaroo Kids International Preschool]] and [[Billabong High International School]].{{cite news|last1=Riaz Usman|first1=Muhammad |title=Incubating the future thinkers, innovators|url=https://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/local/incubating-the-future-thinkers-innovators|accessdate=|publisher=[[Khaleej Times]]|date=23 December 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Choudhary|first1=Anuradha|title=Kangaroo Kids raises $20 million from Gaja Capital |url=https://www.livemint.com/Companies/CTaoSpWMblHrB8aJ8uguOJ/Kangaroo-Kids-raises-20-million-from-Gaja-Capital.html|accessdate=|publisher=[[Mint (newspaper)]]|date=22 March 2017}} Lina has received numerous awards for her work. The most notable award she has received is the Lifetime Award for Achievement in Education by Education World in 2014.{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=IEDRA award for educational excellence|url=http://kalvimalar.dinamalar.com/news-details.asp?cat=1&id=2631|accessdate=|publisher=[[Dinamalar]]|date=2 December 2009}} ==Early life and background== Lina is an [[Australian citizen]] who grew up in [[England]] and presently lives in [[Mumbai]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Ms. Lina Ashar – Founder of Kangaroo Kids of Billabong High International School|url=https://www.indiaschoolnews.com/blog/2016/04/21/ms-lina-ashar-founder-of-kangaroo-kids-of-billabong-high-international-school|accessdate=|publisher=India School News|date=21 April 2016}} She finished her primary schooling in [[England]] and traveled to [[Australia]] to complete her secondary and tertiary schooling in [[Melbourne]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Learning by doing: fun school with a price tag|url=https://www.livemint.com/Companies/pbUqasf1rbQPw7kSsFtaWP/Learning-by-doing-fun-school-with-a-price-tag.html|accessdate=|publisher=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]|date=2 July 2008}} She completed her [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[Education]] from [[Melbourne]]'s [[Victoria College, Melbourne]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Marketing lessons Kangaroo Kids can teach you|url=https://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/marketing/marketing-lessons-kangaroo-kids-can-teach-you/65710145|accessdate=|publisher=[[The Economic Times]]|date=7 September 2018}} ==Career== Lina began her career as a secondary school teacher in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Ms. Lina Ashar, Chairperson, Kangaroo Kids Education Limited|url=https://www.indiainfoline.com/article/news-sector-others/ms-lina-ashar-chairperson-kangaroo-kids-education-limited-113111400406_1.html|accessdate=|publisher=[[India Infoline]]|date=7 April 2006}} In 1990, she took a year-long sabbatical and came to [[India]], while being in touch with her roots, she ended up taking up a school job in [[suburban Mumbai]]. She was surprised to see the education system is in [[India]], so she started the first Kangaroo Kids Preschool in [[Bandra]] in a 650 square feet with a small batch of 25 students and today Kangaroo Kids{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=LiIn the Kanga|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/In-the-Kanga-league/articleshow/262231.cms|accessdate=|publisher=[[Times Internet]]|date=2 November 2003}} is a chain of 70 preschools across [[India]] as well as in [[Dubai]], [[Qatar]], and the [[Maldives]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=How She Did It: Lina Ashar on Building Kangaroo Kids Into A National Chain Of Schools|url=https://www.shethepeople.tv/news/equal-pay-for-equal-work|accessdate=|publisher=SheThePeople.TV|date=6 April 2017}} Later she also founded [[Billabong High International School]] (BHIS) in 2004, which presently has 23 branches at 16 locations across [[India]]. ==Awards and recognition== '''2009:''' * Education Excellence by Indian Economic Development and Research Association{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Lina Ashar receives Lifetime Achievement Award for Educational Excellence|url=http://digitallearning.eletsonline.com/2009/12/lina-ashar-receives-lifetime-achievement-award-for-educational-excellence/|accessdate=|publisher=DigitalLEARNING Magazine|date=11 December 2009}} '''2012:''' * “Education Entrepreneur of the Year” and Indian Education Awards- 2012 presented by Franchise India & [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Award Winners - Indian Education Congress|url=http://www.educationbiz.in/2012/award_winners.php|accessdate=|publisher=Indian Education Congress|date=}} '''2013:''' * Leading Women Entrepreneur by iiGlobal{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Stuti Jalan won the Best Young Women Entrepreneur at the Women Leaders India Awards 2011|url=http://thesmetimes.com/2012/04/26/stuti-jalan-won-the-best-young-women-entrepreneur-at-the-women-leaders-india-awards-2011/|accessdate=|publisher=The SME Times|date=26 April 2012}} '''2014:''' * Lifetime Award for Achievement in Education by Education World{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Lifetime Achievement in Education Leadership: Lina Ashar|url=https://www.educationworld.in/lifetime-achievement-in-education-leadership-lina-ashar/|accessdate=|publisher=Education World, Inc.|date=}} * Panelist at The Economic Times Future of Learning Summit 2014 '''2015:''' * Alumni Excellence Award by [[High Commission of Australia, London|Australian High Commission]]{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Speakers Lina Ashar - TEDx|url=https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/27754|accessdate=|publisher=[[TED (conference)]]|date=}} '''2016:''' * Inspiring Business Leaders India award by [[The Economic Times]] ==Publication== * Who Do You Think You Are Kidding? [[Random House]] [[India]], 2012, {{ISBN|9788184003628}}. * Drama Teen: A Cool-Headed Guide for Parents and Teenagers, [[Random House]] [[India]], 2016, {{ISBN|9789385990724}}. ==See also== * [[Education in India]] * [[Ratan Tata]] * [[Gautam Adani]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External Links== * [https://www.kkel.com/about/the-founder/ Lina Ashar] on ''KKEL'' * [https://www.indiainfoline.com/article/news-sector-others/ms-lina-ashar-chairperson-kangaroo-kids-education-limited-113111400406_1.html Lina Ashar, Chairperson, Kangaroo Kids Education Limited] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ashar, Lina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Mumbai]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]] [[Category:Businesspeople]] [[Category:Educationists]] [[Category:Indian educators‎]] [[Category:Writers from Mumbai]]

{{Infobox person | image =Marijana Matthaus.jpg | alt =Marijana Matthaus in front of a river | caption = | birth_name = Marijana Čolić | birth_date = {{Birth date and age |df=no|1971|09|27}} | birth_place = [[Vrbas, Serbia|Vrbas]], [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] | residence = [[Belgrade]], Serbia | nationality = Serbian | occupation = Business woman, Fashion designer, Entrepreneur, Writer, Former fashion model | years_active = | parents = | relatives = | spouse = [[Miodrag Kostic|Miodrag Kostić]] (1990–1999)
[[Lothar Matthäus]] (2003–2009) | children = 3 }} '''Marijana Matthäus''' ({{lang-sr|Marijana Mateus / Маријана Матеус}}; born September 27, 1971) is an entrepreneur, businesswoman, writer and European socialite based in London, England. She is Founder, Owner and Creative Director of [http://marijanamatthaeus.com/# The Marijana Matthaeus Collection], a luxury fashion brand; [http://luxuniforms.com/# Lux Uniforms], which specializes in custom designed corporate identity business uniforms; [http://andaj.co.uk/# Andaj], a luxury outerwear brand based in London. In recent years, Marijana has grown a significant online and social media presence and will be releasing additional products tied to her name. == Early life and education == Marijana Matthäus, born Marijana Čolić, in Serbia, developed her love for fashion at early age and soon after, her mother began to take her to fashion shows in the country’s Capital, Belgrade. As a young adult, she lived in [[New York City]] where she graduated from The Lubin School of Business in 1999. Years later, she enrolled at the University of Arts London – London College of Fashion in 2014. In addition to that, Marijana also has a bachelor's degree in Pedagogy == Professional career == In 1990, Marijana began her career by creating [http://obucametro.rs# Obuća Metro]," which was a major shoe brand in Serbia and successfully ran the company from 1990 – 1996 as CEO. In 2003, she opened her first fashion boutique "My Style" in [[Budapest]], Hungary, and a second one in 2007 in [[Salzburg]], Austria, where she was living with her second husband [[Lothar Matthäus]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marijanamatthaeus.com/mystyle.html |title=My Style |first=Marijana |last=Matthäus |accessdate=28 October 2011 |work=www.marijanamatthaeus.com}} A few years later, in 2009, Marijana established her own label called [http://marijanamatthaeus.com/# Marijana Class] (later The Marijana Matthaus Collection) and held her creative fashion show debut during Belgrade Fashion Week that same year.{{cite news|title=Revija Marijane Mateus|url=http://www.story.rs/index.php?news=3307|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Story|date=14 April 2009}} On June 1, 2010, Marijana presented her first line of [[swimsuit]]s.{{cite news|language=Serbian |url=http://www.blic.rs/Zabava/Vesti/191179/Marijana-Mateus-kreira-kupace-kostime |title=Marijana Mateus kreira kupaće kostime |date=27 May 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2011 |work=[[Blic]] |first=E. |last=B.}} The creations were worn by competitors in Serbia’s national beauty pageants.{{cite news|language=Serbian |work=[[Blic]] |url=http://www.blic.rs/Zabava/Vesti/192083/Ivana-najlepsa |title=Ivana najlepša |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2011 |first=A, M. |last=B, R.}} Her fashion show ''I Am Mariana'',{{cite news|title=Vatreno plave haljine Marijane Mateus|url=http://www.mondo.rs/s200684/Lifestyle/Vatreno_plave_haljine_Marijane_Mateus.html|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Mondo|date=17 March 2011}} held on 17 March 2011 in the [[Hotel Moskva (Belgrade)|Hotel Moskva]].{{cite news|title=Lotar Mateus na Marijaninoj reviji|url=http://www.blic.rs/Zabava/Vesti/242297/Lotar-Mateus-na-Marijaninoj-reviji|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Blic|date=18 March 2011}} March 2011, the “I am Marijana” Fashion show was held at the prestigious [[Hotel Moskva (Belgrade)|Hotel Moskva]] followed by the Black & White World collection in September 2011.{{cite news|date=21 September 2011 |url=http://www.story.rs/video/18000-crno-beli-svet-marijane-mateus.html |title=Crno-beli svet Marijane Mateus |accessdate=28 October 2011 |language=Serbian |work=Story}} The Flora Fashion Collection was held on the main stage of the Serbian National Theatre in Novi Sad in 2012 and in December of that same year,{{cite news|title=SPEKTAKL U NOVOM SADU: MARIJANA MATEUS U CARSTVU CVEĆA|url=http://www.smedia.rs/zabava/vest/26288/Marijana-Mateus-Revija-Novi-Sad-Spektakl-u-Novom-Sadu-Marijana-Mateus-carstvu-cveca.html|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=S Media|date=11 May 2012}} Marijana held a glamorous fashion show at [[Hotel Moskva (Belgrade)|Hotel Moskva]] once again, where she introduced her new Allure Baroque collection.{{cite news|title=GLAMUROZNO: Marijana Mateus prestavila novu kolekciju!|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/jetset/445726-glamurozno-marijana-mateus-prestavila-novu-kolekciju-foto|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Telegraf|date=7 December 2012}}{{cite news|title=Marijana Mateus predstavila novu kolekciju|url=http://www.svetplus.com/vesti.asp?vid=22954|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Svet Plus|date=6 December 2012}} Marijana expanded her business operations in 2010 and established a new venture called [http://luxuniforms.com/# Lux Uniforms] which specializes in custom designed corporate identity business uniforms and most recently, a new luxury outerwear brand called [http://andaj.co.uk/# Andaj]. This was initially designed for the British market and was launched and presented to media and clients at [http://westburymayfair.com/# The Westbury Hotel] in [[London]], England, in September 2016. Many celebrities and TV personalities often wear her creations, including one the region’s most famous singers, [[Svetlana Ceca Ražnatović]] as well as Milena Vasić, Snežana Dakić, Sanja Marinković, Jelena Jovičić, Vesna Dedić, Katarina Radenković, Ksenija Mijatović.{{cite news|url=http://tracara.com/ceca-u-prilepu-prevazisla-samu-sebe/ |title=Ceca u Prilepu prevazišla samu sebe |work=Tračara.com |language=Serbian |date=20 July 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hellomagazin.rs/ceca-raznatovic-proslavila-rodendan/ |title=Ceca Ražnatović proslavila rođendan |date=15 June 2011 |accessdate=28 October 2011 |language=Serbian |work=[[Hello (magazine)|Hello!]]}}{{cite web|title=Famous in Marijana Class|url=http://www.marijanamatthaeus.com/famous.html|work=Marijana Class|publisher=www.marijanamatthaeus.com|accessdate=5 February 2013}} === Other work and ventures === Marijana Matthäus became the face of the [[Samsung]] football-themed TV campaign in 2006.[http://www.blic.rs/zabava/vesti/marijana-reklamira-samsung/hd3r2rd Article in ''Blic News''] On April 27, 2010, Marijana released her first novel ''Amouage''.{{cite news|title=Marijana Mateus promovisala knjigu|url=http://www.blic.rs/Zabava/Vesti/187178/Marijana-Mateus-promovisala-knjigu|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Blic|date=27 April 2010}}{{cite news|title=Amoaž - iskrena knjiga Marijane Mateus|url=http://www.mondo.rs/s168023/Lifestyle/Amoaz_-_iskrena_knjiga_Marijane_Mateus.html|accessdate=5 February 2013|newspaper=Mondo|date=27 April 2010}} == Personal and media life == Marijana Matthäus married one of the most successful businessmen in the region, [[Miodrag Kostic|Miodrag Kostić]], in 1990 and have 3 children together. Her second husband was German football coach and former player [[Lothar Matthäus]]. Matthäus currently divides her time between [[London]], [[Budapest]] and [[Belgrade]]. She is fluent in 5 languages - Serbian, English, Italian, Hungarian and German.{{cite news|work=Puls |accessdate=28 October 2011 |year=2006 |language=Serbian |url=http://www.pulsonline.rs/lifestyle/na-kafi-kod/12/marijana-mateus-zena-koja-zivi-kako-zeli |title=Marijana Mateus: Žena koja živi kako želi |first=Simonida |last=Stanković}}{{cite news|work=[[Politika]] |url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/zivot-i-stil/zenska-strana/Dva-uspeshna-muza-i-kolekcija.lt.html |title=Dva uspešna muža i kolekcija |language=Serbian |first=Zorica |last=Karanović |accessdate=28 October 2011 |date=10 April 2008}} Marijana is also known for her philanthropic endeavors and regularly gives to a number of charities and causes.{{cite news|url=http://www.svet.rs/clanak/marijana-mateus-priprema-humanitarni-bal |date=27 January 2010 |title=Marijana Mateus priprema humanitarni bal |work=Svet |language=Serbian |accessdate=28 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.story.rs/video/7234-svetosavski-bal.html |title=Svetosavski bal |date=29 January 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2011 |language=Serbian |work=Story}}{{cite news|url=http://195.178.48.167/rubrike/spektar/zenska-strana/Bal-vracen-medju-oficire.lt.html |title=Bal vraćen među oficire |date=31 January 2011 |language=Serbian |accessdate=28 October 2011 |work=[[Politika]]}} She regularly asks local celebrities to donate some of their belongings and proceeds to charities that help women in need. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.marijanamatthaeus.com/ Official Website] * http://luxuniforms.com/ * http://andaj.co.uk/ {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matthaeus, Marijana}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Belgrade]] [[Category:People from Vrbas, Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]] [[Category:Serbian fashion designers]] [[Category:Serbian female models]] [[Category:Serbian novelists]] [[Category:Serbian autobiographers]] [[Category:Serbian socialites]] [[Category:Women autobiographers]] [[Category:Serbian women in business]]
